Introduction to Microeconomics:

  • Economics is the study of the allocation of resources.
  • Why is economics important?
    The economic problem of scarcity:
    • Limited resources vs. Unlimited wants

Scope of Microeconomics:

  • Analysis of individual units of the economy:
    • Factors determining the behavior of consumers
    • Behavior of producers
    • Demand for a good
    • Supply of a good
    • Price of a good
    • Quantity of a good
    • Performance of a market

Behavior of Consumers:

  • Utility Function:
    U=U(x1,x2,…,xN) U = U(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_N) U=U(x1​,x2​,…,xN​)

  • Budget Constraint:
    M=P1x1+P2x2+⋯+PNxN M = P_1 x_1 + P_2 x_2 + \dots + P_N x_N M=P1​x1​+P2​x2​+⋯+PN​xN​

Why study consumer behavior?

To derive the Demand Curve.

Maximization Problem:

Lagrangian Function:
L=U(x1,x2,…,xN)+λ[M−(P1x1+P2x2+⋯+PNxN)] L = U(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_N) + \lambda \left[ M - (P_1 x_1 + P_2 x_2 + \dots + P_N x_N) \right] L=U(x1​,x2​,…,xN​)+λ[M−(P1​x1​+P2​x2​+⋯+PN​xN​)]

Maximize (L)( L )(L) with respect to (x1,x2,…,xN)( x_1, x_2, \dots, x_N )(x1​,x2​,…,xN​).

First Order Conditions (F.O.Cs):

  • How many F.O.Cs?
    N+1 N + 1 N+1
    (N variables and 1 constraint)

  • Hessian Bordered Determinant
    (Please revise from Intermediate Microeconomics by Hal Varian)

Properties of Well-Behaved Indifference Curves:

  1. Convex to the origin.
  2. Do not intersect.
  3. Higher indifference curves indicate higher utility.

What happens when these properties are violated?

How do we get the demand curve?

  • The demand curve shows the relationship between the price and the quantity demanded for the same good.
  • Here, we have a relationship between the quantities of two goods.

To derive the demand curve:

  • Price Consumption Curve (PCC): It is a locus of all equilibrium points when the price of good 1 changes.
  • We can generate the demand curve from the PCC, which relates (P1)( P_1)(P1​) and (x1)( x_1 )(x1​).

Suppose (P1)( P_1 )(P1​) increases. What happens to the indifference curve?

  • Utility function remains unchanged:
    U=U(x1,x2)=constant U = U(x_1, x_2) = \text{constant} U=U(x1​,x2​)=constant

  • Budget constraint:
    M=P1x1+P2x2 M = P_1 x_1 + P_2 x_2 M=P1​x1​+P2​x2​
    Solving for (x2)( x_2 )(x2​):
    x2=MP2−P1P2x1 x_2 = \frac{M}{P_2} - \frac{P_1}{P_2} x_1 x2​=P2​M​−P2​P1​​x1​

  • As (P1)( P_1 )(P1​) increases, the budget line swings inwards, reflecting reduced purchasing power.

  • The PCC represents the changing equilibrium as (P1)( P_1 )(P1​) varies.

Deriving the demand curve:

  • As (P1)( P_1 )(P1​) increases from (P1)( P_1 )(P1​) to (P1′)( P_1' )(P1′​) to (P1′′)( P_1'' )(P1′′​),
    (x1)( x_1 )(x1​) decreases from (x1)( x_1 )(x1​) to (x1′)( x_1' )(x1′​) to (x1′′)( x_1'' )(x1′′​).

  • Is the demand curve always downward sloping?
    Not necessarily, but typically, the relation between (P1)( P_1 )(P1​) and (x1)( x_1 )(x1​) is downward sloping:

    ∂x1∂P1<0 \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial P_1} < 0 ∂P1​∂x1​​<0

  • Hence, the demand curve DDD is downward sloping.

Market Demand:

  • The market consists of several consumers.
    How do we derive the market demand curve?
    Through horizontal summation of each individual’s demand curve.

Production Behavior:

  • We start with a production function:
    Q=f(z1,z2,…,zN) Q = f(z_1, z_2, \dots, z_N) Q=f(z1​,z2​,…,zN​)
    Simplified to:
    Q=f(K,L) Q = f(K, L) Q=f(K,L)
    where KKK represents capital and LLL represents labor.

  • Short Run (SR) vs Long Run (LR):

    • In the SR, some inputs (like capital) are fixed.
    • In the LR, all inputs are variable.

Short Run Production:

  • Law of Variable Proportion (Returns to a factor):

    1. Stage I: Increasing returns to a factor.
    2. Stage II: Diminishing returns to a factor.
    3. Stage III: Negative returns to a factor.

  • Costs of Production:

    • Fixed cost, variable cost, average cost, marginal cost.
    • The relationship between production stages and costs.

Long Run Production:

  • In the LR, all factors are variable, leading to different behavior for the firm.

    Why study this?

    • To derive the firm’s supply curve, and subsequently, the market supply curve.

Production Function Revisited:

  • Production function:
    Q=f(K,L) Q = f(K, L) Q=f(K,L)

  • Cost constraint:
    C=wL+rK C = wL + rK C=wL+rK
    where www is the wage rate and rrr is the rental rate of capital.

  • Profit function:
    π=P⋅f(K,L)−wL−rK \pi = P \cdot f(K, L) - wL - rK π=P⋅f(K,L)−wL−rK

    • Two variables: KKK and LLL.
    • You get two first-order conditions (F.O.Cs) to determine equilibrium.

Graphical Representation:

  • Isoquant: Graphical representation of combinations of KKK and LLL that yield the same level of output.
  • Producer’s Equilibrium: Derive the firm’s supply curve from the equilibrium point.

Market Supply:

  • The total market supply is the horizontal summation of individual firm supply curves.

Please refer to Intermediate Microeconomics for a quick revision of concepts like substitution and income effects, diminishing marginal utility, and production behavior.

Once you have your market demand and market supply curves, you can analyze markets.

Types of Market Structures:

  • Perfect Competition
  • Monopoly
  • Oligopoly
  • Monopolistic Competition
  • Monopsony

Chapter 1 : Technology

To understand the technology of a firm, the production function is the easiest way to summarize it. General and useful ways to understand technology involve understanding firms’ production possibilities.

Measurement of Inputs and Outputs

A firm produces output from various combinations of inputs. Suppose:

  • (q)( q )(q) is the output,
  • (L)( L )(L) is labor,
  • (K)( K )(K) is capital.

We can express this relationship as:
q=f(L,K) q = f(L, K) q=f(L,K)
For specific combinations:

  • (q=f(1,2))( q = f(1, 2) )(q=f(1,2))
  • (q=f(2,2))( q = f(2, 2) )(q=f(2,2))
  • (q=f(2,1))( q = f(2, 1) )(q=f(2,1))

This representation shows the combinations of inputs and output that the firm is able to produce.

General Argument:
To study firm choices, we need a structured and convenient way to summarize the production possibilities of the firm.

What are Production Possibilities?

Production possibilities refer to the combinations of inputs and outputs that are technologically feasible for a firm. This concept is crucial in understanding how firms utilize their resources efficiently to produce goods and services.

Key Points:

  1. Inputs and Outputs:

    • In production, both inputs (like labor and capital) and outputs (the goods produced) flow over a specific period.
    • For example, a certain amount of inputs are used to produce a specific quantity of output during that period.

  2. Time Dimension:

    • When specifying inputs, it is essential to include a time dimension.
    • For instance, labor can be measured in hours worked per week, while capital can be assessed based on the amount spent on machinery per month.
    • Important Note: It’s crucial to use the same time unit for analysis to ensure consistency.

  3. Spatial and Temporal Nature of Production:

    • Some aspects of production involve spatial and temporal considerations.
    • For example, concrete that is available in a given year may be used to construct a building in the following year.
    • Similarly, concrete used in your city might have been sourced from a neighboring state. Therefore, the input “concrete” must be understood as available in a specific location at a particular time.

Takeaway:

All these points are vital when analyzing producers’ behavior and focusing on inputs and outputs. However, it is common for us to overlook these aspects in formal discussions. This oversight does not imply that these factors are unimportant; rather, it is often assumed that they are adequately accounted for in the analysis.

Specification of Technology

The specification of technology provides a general framework that captures the same intuition but offers a different formalization for studying production behavior.

General Framework:

  • Consider a firm that has nnn possible goods.
  • This framework is general because it allows all nnn possible goods to serve as inputs and/or outputs.

Inputs and Outputs:

  • It’s easy to think of examples where certain goods act purely as inputs or outputs.
  • Examples:
    • In chemical production, heat can serve as both an input (for energy) and an output (as a byproduct).

Notation:

  • Let yjiy_j^iyji​ represent the units of good jjj used as an input.
  • Let yjoy_j^oyjo​ represent the units of good jjj produced as an output.
  • The net output of good jjj is given by:
    yj=yjo−yji y_j = y_j^o - y_j^i yj​=yjo​−yji​
  • If yjo>yjiy_j^o > y_j^iyjo​>yji​, the firm is producing more of good jjj than it is using.
  • Conversely, if yjo<yjiy_j^o < y_j^iyjo​<yji​, the firm is using more of good jjj as an input (e.g., curd) and producing less of it (e.g., heat).

Production Plan:

A production plan lists the net outputs of various goods. It can be represented as a vector:
y=(y1,y2,…,ym) y = (y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_m) y=(y1​,y2​,…,ym​)
where yyy is in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn.

Production Possibility Set (PPS):

The set of all technologically feasible production plans is called the Production Possibility Set (PPS), denoted as YYY.

  • YYY is obviously a subset of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn and describes all patterns of inputs and outputs that are technologically feasible, providing a complete description of the firm’s technological possibilities.

Examining Technological Possibility Set:

We may want to distinguish between production plans that are “immediately” feasible and those that are “eventually” feasible. This distinction aligns with the familiar discussion of the short run (SR) and the long run (LR).

Short Run vs. Long Run:

  • In the short run, since some factors are fixed, production plans must take these restrictions into account.
  • We will assume that all restrictions faced by the firm in the short run are described by a vector zzz in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn.
    • Think of zzz as the list of the maximum amounts of various inputs and outputs that can be produced in the concerned period.

Restricted Production Possibility Set:

We use a restricted production possibility set denoted by Y(z)Y(z)Y(z) (in the short run, this is called the SR PPS).
Y(z)={y∈Y:Yj=yj} Y(z) = \{ y \in Y : Y_j = y_j \} Y(z)={y∈Y:Yj​=yj​}

  • Here, Y(z)Y(z)Y(z) consists of all feasible net output bundles consistent with the set of restrictions.
  • Example: If a factor is fixed at yny_nyn​ in the SR, then the SR PPS can be defined as:
    Y(yˉn)={y∈Y:yn=yˉn} Y(\bar y_n ) = \{ y \in Y : y_n =\bar y_n \} Y(yˉ​n​)={y∈Y:yn​=yˉ​n​}

Conclusion:

The set Y(z)Y(z)Y(z) is a subset of YYY because it contains all production plans that satisfy the additional conditions imposed by the input requirements.

Input Requirement Set

Suppose a firm produces a single output, denoted as yyy, while the rest of the goods are inputs. We can denote the vector of inputs as x=(x1,x2,…,xn)x = (x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n)x=(x1​,x2​,…,xn​). The production process can be expressed as the net output bundle (y,−x)(y, - x)(y,−x), where yyy represents the units of output produced.

A special case of the restricted production possibilities set is the input requirement set, denoted as V(y)V(y)V(y). It is defined as:
V(y)={x∈R+n:(y,−x)∈Y} V(y) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n_+ : (y, -x) \in Y \} V(y)={x∈R+n​:(y,−x)∈Y}
This set describes the real space of nnn dimensions in the positive space.

Properties of V(y)V(y)V(y):

  • V(y)V(y)V(y) has two parts:
    1. All inputs are constrained in the positive real space.
    2. The net output bundle associated with these inputs is technologically feasible.

Thus, V(y)V(y)V(y) is the set of all input bundles that can produce at least yyy units of output.

Important Note:

The input requirement set defines inputs as positive numbers, which is the opposite of how inputs are defined in the Production Possibility Set (PPS).

Isoquant Definition

We can define an isoquant using the concept of the input requirement set. Let V(y)V(y)V(y) be the set of all input bundles producing at least yyy units of output.

For all input bundles that produce exactly yyy units of output, we define:
Q(y)={x∈R+n:x∈V(y) and x produces exactly y units of output} Q(y) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n_+ : x \in V(y) \text{ and } x \text{ produces exactly } y \text{ units of output} \} Q(y)={x∈R+n​:x∈V(y) and x produces exactly y units of output}

Example: Short Run Production Possibility Set (SR PPS)

Suppose a firm produces output from labor and capital. The production plan can be represented as (y,−l,−k)(y, -l, -k)(y,−l,−k), leading to the PPS defined as:
Y={(y,−l,−k)∈Y} Y = \{ (y, -l, -k) \in Y \} Y={(y,−l,−k)∈Y}

Now, if we can change the labor input but the capital is fixed at kˉ\bar kkˉ, then we have:
Y(z)→Y(kˉ)={(y,−l,−k)∈Y:k=kˉ} Y(z) \rightarrow Y(\bar k) = \{ (y, -l, -k) \in Y : k = \bar k \} Y(z)→Y(kˉ)={(y,−l,−k)∈Y:k=kˉ}
This shows how the production possibility set adjusts based on fixed and variable inputs in the short run.

Production Function

If a firm produces one output, we define the production function as follows:
f(x)={y∈R:y is the maximum output associated with x in Y} f(x) = \{ y \in \mathbb{R} : y \text{ is the maximum output associated with } x \text{ in } Y \} f(x)={y∈R:y is the maximum output associated with x in Y}
This function relates the input vector xxx to the maximum possible output yyy that can be produced by the firm.

Transformation Function

The concept of a production function can be extended into a higher dimensional analog, known as the transformation function. It is defined as:
T:Rn→R T : \mathbb{R}^n \rightarrow \mathbb{R} T:Rn→R
The transformation function T(y)=0T(y) = 0T(y)=0 if and only if yyy represents an efficient production plan.

What do we mean by “efficient”?

A production plan yyy is said to be efficient if there is no other production plan y′y'y′ such that y≤y′y \leq y'y≤y′ and y′≠yy' \neq yy′=y. In simple terms, this means that a production plan is efficient if there is no way to produce more output with the same inputs or produce the same output with fewer inputs.

Recap of Notations:

  • We began with a set of goods, indexed by j=1,2,…,nj = 1, 2, \ldots, nj=1,2,…,n.
  • Let yjoy_j^oyjo​ represent the amount of output of good jjj, and yjiy_j^iyji​ represent the amount of input of good jjj.
  • The net output vector is y=(y1,y2,…,yn)y = (y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n)y=(y1​,y2​,…,yn​), where yj>0y_j > 0yj​>0 for outputs and yj≤0y_j \leq 0yj​≤0 for inputs.
  • The Production Possibility Set (PPS) is denoted by YYY, and it describes all feasible net output vectors.

Examples:

  1. Production Plan:
    A production plan is represented as y=(y1,y2,…,yn)y = (y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n)y=(y1​,y2​,…,yn​), where yjy_jyj​ indicates the net output of good jjj.

  2. Short Run Production Possibility Set (SR PPS):
    The SR PPS is restricted to certain inputs that are fixed in the short run. We denote the input requirement set as V(y)V(y)V(y), and it represents all input bundles that can produce at least yyy units of output.

  3. Production Function (f(x)f(x)f(x)):
    The production function describes the maximum output that can be produced from a given input bundle xxx. For example, the Cobb-Douglas production function with inputs x1,x2x_1, x_2x1​,x2​ is given by:
    f(x1,x2)=Ax1αx21−α f(x_1, x_2) = A x_1^\alpha x_2^{1-\alpha} f(x1​,x2​)=Ax1α​x21−α​

  4. Isoquant:
    The isoquant B(y)B(y)B(y) represents all input bundles that produce exactly yyy units of output. It is defined as:
    Q(y)={x∈Rn:f(x)=y} Q(y) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R}^n : f(x) = y \} Q(y)={x∈Rn:f(x)=y}

Cobb-Douglas Production Function Example:

Suppose a firm has two inputs, x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​, and produces output yyy. The Cobb-Douglas production function is:
f(x1,x2)=Ax1αx21−α f(x_1, x_2) = A x_1^\alpha x_2^{1-\alpha} f(x1​,x2​)=Ax1α​x21−α​
The associated production plan is represented as (y,−x1,−x2)(y, -x_1, -x_2)(y,−x1​,−x2​), and the production possibility set (PPS) is:
Y={(y,−x1,−x2)∈R3:y≤Ax1αx21−α} Y = \{ (y, -x_1, -x_2) \in \mathbb{R}^3 : y \leq A x_1^\alpha x_2^{1-\alpha} \} Y={(y,−x1​,−x2​)∈R3:y≤Ax1α​x21−α​}
and the input requirement set:
V(y)={(x1,x2)∈R+2:y≤Ax1αx21−α} V(y) = \{ ( x_1, x_2) \in \mathbb{R}^2_+ : y \leq A x_1^\alpha x_2^{1-\alpha} \} V(y)={(x1​,x2​)∈R+2​:y≤Ax1α​x21−α​}

Isoquant:

Q(y)={(x1,x2)∈R+2:y=x1ax21−a} Q(y) = \{(x_1, x_2) \in \mathbb{R}_+^2 : y = x_1^a x_2^{1-a} \} Q(y)={(x1​,x2​)∈R+2​:y=x1a​x21−a​}

Suppose x2=zx_2 = zx2​=z, Restricted Production Possibility Set:

Y(z)={(y,−x1,−x2)∈R3:y≤x1ax21−a,x2=z} Y(z) = \{(y, -x_1, -x_2) \in \mathbb{R}^3 : y \leq x_1^a x_2^{1-a}, x_2 = z \} Y(z)={(y,−x1​,−x2​)∈R3:y≤x1a​x21−a​,x2​=z}

Transformation Function:

T(y)=0⇒y−f(x)=0⇒y−x1ax21−a=0 T(y) = 0 \Rightarrow y - f(x) = 0 \Rightarrow y - x_1^a x_2^{1-a} = 0 T(y)=0⇒y−f(x)=0⇒y−x1a​x21−a​=0

Production Function:

f(x1,x2)=x1ax21−a f(x_1, x_2) = x_1^a x_2^{1-a} f(x1​,x2​)=x1a​x21−a​

Leontief Technology Example:

In Leontief technology, the production function assumes perfect complements between inputs, and output is determined by the minimum of the scaled inputs. The production function is:
f(x1,x2)=min⁡(ax1,bx2) f(x_1, x_2) = \min(a x_1, b x_2) f(x1​,x2​)=min(ax1​,bx2​)
Y→{(y,−x1,−x2)∈R3:y≤min⁡(ax1,bx2)} Y \rightarrow \{ (y,-x_1, -x_2) \in \mathbb{R}^3 : y \leq \min(a x_1, b x_2) \} Y→{(y,−x1​,−x2​)∈R3:y≤min(ax1​,bx2​)}
The input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y) is defined as:
V(y)={(x1,x2)∈R+2:y≤min⁡(ax1,bx2)} V(y) = \{ (x_1, x_2) \in \mathbb{R}^2_+ : y \leq \min(a x_1, b x_2) \} V(y)={(x1​,x2​)∈R+2​:y≤min(ax1​,bx2​)}
Q(y)={(x1,x2)∈R+2:y=min⁡(ax1,bx2)} Q(y) = \{(x_1, x_2) \in \mathbb{R}_+^2 : y = \min(a x_1, b x_2) \} Q(y)={(x1​,x2​)∈R+2​:y=min(ax1​,bx2​)}
The transformation function T(y,x1,x2)T(y, x_1, x_2)T(y,x1​,x2​) is:
T(y,x1,x2)=y−min⁡(ax1,bx2) T(y, x_1, x_2) = y - \min(a x_1, b x_2) T(y,x1​,x2​)=y−min(ax1​,bx2​)

Summary:

We have explored the key technical and formal methods used to describe various aspects of production possibilities. We will now focus on the description of the methods used. In this part of the course, we focus on the assumption that a firm is producing a single output, and much of the analysis revolves around describing the technology using the input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y) and the transformation function T(y)T(y)T(y).

Activity Analysis

This focuses on how to describe production processes. The simplest way to describe production using input requirement sets is to simply list them!

Example:

Suppose we have an output good, produced using two factor inputs: factor 1 and factor 2. There are two different activities or techniques by which this production takes place. To produce 1 unit of the output good, we can do either of the following:

  1. Technique 1: 1 unit of factor 1 and 2 units of factor 2 →\rightarrow→ 1 unit of output.
  2. Technique 2: 2 units of factor 1 and 1 unit of factor 2 →\rightarrow→ 1 unit of output.

Now, let’s further define the goods:

  • Suppose output is good 1.
  • Input 1 is good 2.
  • Input 2 is good 3.

Production Possibility Set:

Y={(1,−2,−1),(1,−1,−2)} Y = \{(1, -2, -1), (1, -1, -2)\} Y={(1,−2,−1),(1,−1,−2)}

Input Requirement Set:

For 1 unit of output, the input requirement set is:
V(1)={(2,1),(1,2)} V(1) = \{(2, 1), (1, 2)\} V(1)={(2,1),(1,2)}

Now, if I ask you, what is V(y)V(y)V(y)? That is, what is the set of feasible ways to produce yyy units of output?

V(y)={(y,2y),(2y,y)} V(y) = \{(y, 2y), (2y, y)\} V(y)={(y,2y),(2y,y)}

Does this set include all relevant possibilities? Not quite! Why?

  • It is true that (y,2y)(y, 2y)(y,2y) produces yyy units if we use technique A.
  • Similarly, (2y,y)(2y, y)(2y,y) produces yyy units if we use technique B.

But what if we use a mixture of techniques A and B?

Accurate Input Requirement Set:

Let us try to formulate a more accurate input requirement set for y=1,2,…y = 1, 2, \dotsy=1,2,…. Let:

  • YAY_AYA​ be the amount of output produced by technique A.
  • YBY_BYB​ be the amount of output produced by technique B.

The input requirement set for yyy can then be written as:
V(y)={(YA+2YB,YB+2YA):y=YA+YB} V(y) = \{(Y_A + 2Y_B, Y_B + 2Y_A): y = Y_A + Y_B \} V(y)={(YA​+2YB​,YB​+2YA​):y=YA​+YB​}

So, for example:

  • V(1)={(1,2),(2,1)}V(1) = \{(1, 2), (2, 1)\}V(1)={(1,2),(2,1)}
  • V(2)={(2,4),(4,2),(3,3)}V(2) = \{(2, 4), (4, 2), (3, 3)\}V(2)={(2,4),(4,2),(3,3)}
  • V(3)={(3,6),(6,3),(5,4),(4,5)}V(3) = \{(3, 6), (6, 3), (5, 4), (4, 5)\}V(3)={(3,6),(6,3),(5,4),(4,5)}

And so on…

Thus, for the given technological specification, the set:
V(y)={(YA+2YB,2YA+YB):y=YA+YB} V(y) = \{(Y_A + 2Y_B, 2Y_A + Y_B): y = Y_A + Y_B \} V(y)={(YA​+2YB​,2YA​+YB​):y=YA​+YB​}
is a more appropriate description of the input requirement set.

Monotonic Technologies:

Now, let’s focus on some properties of this input requirement set.

In this two-technique example, suppose we have an input vector of (3,2)(3, 2)(3,2). Then, if I ask you: Is this sufficient to produce 1 unit of output?

Your answer should be Yes! Why?

Because either technique 1 or technique 2 will allow us to produce 1 unit of output. However, we would need to dispose of the extra inputs along the way.

If such free disposal is allowed, it is reasonable to argue that:

  • If xxx is a feasible vector of inputs that produces yyy units of output,
  • Then, any input vector x′x'x′, with at least as much of each input as xxx, should also be feasible to produce yyy.

Thus, the input requirement set is monotonic:
If x∈V(y) and x′≥x, then x′∈V(y). \text{If } x \in V(y) \text{ and } x' \geq x \text{, then } x' \in V(y). If x∈V(y) and x′≥x, then x′∈V(y).

Similarly, for production sets:

  • If y∈Yy \in Yy∈Y and y′≤yy' \leq yy′≤y, then y′y'y′ is in YYY.
  • This means that production plan y′y'y′ produces equal or smaller amounts of output by using at least as much inputs as yyy.

Naturally, if yyy is feasible, then y′y'y′ is also feasible.

Convex Technologies

Now, using the same two techniques, suppose we want to produce 100 units of output. The question arises:

What will the input requirement set look like?

The straightforward answer: We could replicate the process and thereby produce 100 times as much.

Is this realistic? Not always!

Suppose it is realistic, then using V(1)={(1,2),(2,1)}V(1) = \{(1, 2), (2, 1)\}V(1)={(1,2),(2,1)}, we can replicate it for y=100y = 100y=100. This would give us the input combinations:
V(100)={(100,200),(200,100)} V(100) = \{(100, 200), (200, 100)\} V(100)={(100,200),(200,100)}

Any other possible ways to produce 100 units of output?

Consider the following:

  • 50 units of activity A and 50 units of activity B.

  • 50 units of activity A uses the combination (100,50)(100, 50)(100,50).

  • 50 units of activity B uses the combination (50,100)(50, 100)(50,100).

Hence, these combinations would use 150 units of input 1 and 150 units of input 2. So, (150,150)(150, 150)(150,150) should also be in V(100)V(100)V(100).

Another scenario:

Suppose we want to use the following combination:

  • 25 processes of activity A: (50,25)(50, 25)(50,25).
  • 75 processes of activity B: (25,150)(25, 150)(25,150).

Thus, the input combination (125,175)(125, 175)(125,175) should also be in V(100)V(100)V(100).

Generalization:

Let’s make this more general. If we use a weighted combination of the two techniques, we get:
t(100,200)+(1−t)(200,100)=(100t+200(1−t),200t+100(1−t)) t(100, 200) + (1-t)(200, 100) = (100t + 200(1-t), 200t + 100(1-t)) t(100,200)+(1−t)(200,100)=(100t+200(1−t),200t+100(1−t))
This should also be in V(100)V(100)V(100), where 0≤t≤10 \leq t \leq 10≤t≤1.

This property is called Convexity.

Convexity Property:


For the input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y), if xxx and x′x'x′ are in V(y)V(y)V(y), then any convex combination of xxx and x′x'x′ is also in V(y)V(y)V(y). Mathematically:
tx+(1−t)x′∈V(y)for all 0≤t≤1 tx + (1-t)x' \in V(y) \quad \text{for all } 0 \leq t \leq 1 tx+(1−t)x′∈V(y)for all 0≤t≤1
Thus, V(y)V(y)V(y) is a convex set.

Is convexity a reasonable assumption?

When scaling up from small to large outputs, convexity is a reasonable assumption. However, this can be questionable because, at times, the scale of the underlying activities may become too large.

Convexity may not be reasonable under certain assumptions but may be reasonable in other circumstances. For example:

  • Suppose we measure output per month.
  • If activity A produces yyy units of output in one month, and activity B also produces yyy units in one month, then we can split the processes.
  • We can use half of activity A for the first half of the month and half of activity B for the second half, producing yyy units of output.

Convexity Assumption for Production Set:

If yyy is in YYY and y′y'y′ is in YYY, then the convex combination:
ty+(1−t)y′∈Yfor all 0≤t≤1 ty + (1-t)y' \in Y \quad \text{for all } 0 \leq t \leq 1 ty+(1−t)y′∈Yfor all 0≤t≤1
implies that YYY is a convex set.

A Simple Property:

One simple property of a convex production set is that it implies a convex input requirement set as well.

To Prove: If the Production Set YYY is Convex, the Associated Input Requirement Set is also Convex

Statement:

We are tasked with proving that if the production set YYY is convex, then the associated input requirement set is also convex.

Proof:

Let’s assume that YYY is a convex set. This implies that for any xxx and x′x'x′, if (y,x)(y, x)(y,x) is in YYY and (y,x′)(y, x')(y,x′) is also in YYY, then the convex combination of these points must also be in YYY. This can be written as:
(ty+(1−t)y,−tx−(1−t)x′)∈Yfor all 0≤t≤1 (ty + (1 - t)y, -tx - (1 - t)x') \in Y \quad \text{for all } 0 \leq t \leq 1 (ty+(1−t)y,−tx−(1−t)x′)∈Yfor all 0≤t≤1

Now, if (y,−x)∈Y(y, -x) \in Y(y,−x)∈Y and (y,−x′)∈Y(y, -x') \in Y(y,−x′)∈Y, it follows that the convex combination (y,−tx−(1−t)x′)∈Y(y, -tx - (1 - t)x') \in Y(y,−tx−(1−t)x′)∈Y. This implies that for the input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y):
tx+(1−t)x′∈V(y) tx + (1 - t)x' \in V(y) tx+(1−t)x′∈V(y)

Thus, the input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y) is convex, meaning that any convex combination of feasible input vectors is also feasible for producing the same level of output.

Regular Technologies

Regular Conditions for the Input Requirement Set V(y)V(y)V(y):

A weak regular condition for the input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y) is that V(y)V(y)V(y) should satisfy the following two properties:

  1. Closed: The set V(y)V(y)V(y) must be a closed set.
  2. Non-empty: The set V(y)V(y)V(y) should not be empty for all y>0y > 0y>0.

Assumption 1: V(y)V(y)V(y) is Non-empty

The assumption that V(y)V(y)V(y) is non-empty requires that producing some output is not trivial. Specifically, we cannot assume that yyy can always be produced without inputs. There must be some conceivable way to produce output.

Assumption 2: V(y)V(y)V(y) is Closed

If V(y)V(y)V(y) is closed, it means that if we have a sequence of input vectors {xi}\{x^i\}{xi}, each of which can produce yyy units of output, and if this sequence converges to some point x0x^0x0, then x0x^0x0 must also be capable of producing yyy.

In other words, the input requirement set must include its boundary. If inputs converge to a limit, that limit must also be feasible.

Parametric Representation of Technology

Introduction:

Suppose there are many possible ways to produce a given level of output. Instead of listing all possible input combinations, we can smooth the associated isoquants and represent the technology using parametric functions.

The smoothing of isoquants provides a convenient way to represent production technology through mathematical functions.

Parametric Representations:

Some common parametric forms used to represent technologies include:

  • Cobb-Douglas production function,
  • Constant elasticity of substitution (CES),
  • Leontief function,
  • Linear functions, and
  • Others.

Why Use Parametric Specifications?

The reason for applying a parametric specification to physical data is to use pedagogic tools such as calculus and algebra. These tools allow us to analyze production processes more rigorously.

Once we bring the discussion into the realm of algebra and calculus, we can explore more algebraic properties of production processes. This includes discussing concepts related to technology, isoquants, and input-output relationships.

Conclusion:

In summary, if the production set YYY is convex, the input requirement set V(y)V(y)V(y) will also be convex. Regular technologies must satisfy the conditions of being non-empty and closed, and parametric representations of production functions help simplify the analysis of complex production technologies.

Technical Rate of Substitution (TRS)

Assumptions:

Assume that we have a technology represented by a smooth production function:
y∗=f(x1,x2) y^* = f(x_1, x_2) y∗=f(x1​,x2​)

This production function expresses the output yyy as a function of two inputs, x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​. Now, suppose we are at a particular point (x1∗,x2∗)(x_1^*, x_2^*)(x1∗​,x2∗​) on the production function, producing a certain level of output yyy. The production function at this point is:
y∗=f(x1∗,x2∗) y^* = f(x_1^*, x_2^*) y∗=f(x1∗​,x2∗​)

Concept of TRS:

If we want to increase the amount of input x1x_1x1​ but maintain the same level of output y∗y^*y∗, we must reduce the amount of input x2x_2x2​. This trade-off between the two inputs, while keeping output constant, is referred to as the Technical Rate of Substitution (TRS).

TRS is defined as the amount of one input that has to be sacrificed to use an additional unit of the other input, while maintaining the same level of output.

Interpretation:

TRS represents the slope of the isoquant. The isoquant is a curve that shows all possible combinations of inputs that produce the same level of output.

Derivation of TRS:

There are two primary methods to derive the TRS.

Method 1: Using the Implicit Function Theorem

Let x2(x1)x_2(x_1)x2​(x1​) be the implicit function that tells us how much of input x2x_2x2​ is required to produce yyy, using x1x_1x1​ units of the other input.

Given the production function:
f(x1,x2(x1))=y f(x_1, x_2(x_1)) = y f(x1​,x2​(x1​))=y

Differentiate this with respect to x1x_1x1​:
∂f∂x1+∂f∂x2⋅dx2dx1=0 \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot \frac{dx_2}{dx_1} = 0 ∂x1​∂f​+∂x2​∂f​⋅dx1​dx2​​=0

Solving for dx2dx1\frac{dx_2}{dx_1}dx1​dx2​​:
dx2dx1=−∂f∂x1∂f∂x2 \frac{dx_2}{dx_1} = -\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1}}{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}} dx1​dx2​​=−∂x2​∂f​∂x1​∂f​​

Thus, the TRS is given by:
TRS=dx2dx1=−∂f∂x1∂f∂x2 \text{TRS} = \frac{dx_2}{dx_1} = -\frac{ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} }{ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} } TRS=dx1​dx2​​=−∂x2​∂f​∂x1​∂f​​

Method 2: Using Total Differentiation

Consider the total differential of the production function:
y=f(x1,x2) y = f(x_1, x_2) y=f(x1​,x2​)

Taking the total differential:
dy=∂f∂x1⋅dx1+∂f∂x2⋅dx2 dy = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \cdot dx_1 + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot dx_2 dy=∂x1​∂f​⋅dx1​+∂x2​∂f​⋅dx2​

To maintain the same level of output yyy, we set dy=0dy = 0dy=0:
0=∂f∂x1⋅dx1+∂f∂x2⋅dx2 0 = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \cdot dx_1 + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot dx_2 0=∂x1​∂f​⋅dx1​+∂x2​∂f​⋅dx2​

Solving for dx2dx1\frac{dx_2}{dx_1}dx1​dx2​​:
dx2dx1=−∂f∂x1∂f∂x2 \frac{dx_2}{dx_1} = -\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1}}{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}} dx1​dx2​​=−∂x2​∂f​∂x1​∂f​​

Thus, the TRS is:
TRS=−∂f∂x1∂f∂x2 \text{TRS} = -\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1}}{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}} TRS=−∂x2​∂f​∂x1​∂f​​

Examples of TRS for Different Production Functions

1. TRS for a Cobb-Douglas Production Function

The Cobb-Douglas production function is given by:
y=Ax1ax21−a y = A x_1^a x_2^{1-a} y=Ax1a​x21−a​

First, compute the partial derivatives:
∂f∂x1=aAx1a−1x21−a \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} = a A x_1^{a-1} x_2^{1-a} ∂x1​∂f​=aAx1a−1​x21−a​
∂f∂x2=(1−a)Ax1ax2−a \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} = (1 - a) A x_1^a x_2^{-a} ∂x2​∂f​=(1−a)Ax1a​x2−a​

Now, the TRS is:
TRS=−∂f∂x1∂f∂x2=−aAx1a−1x21−a(1−a)Ax1ax2−a \text{TRS} = -\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1}}{\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2}} = -\frac{a A x_1^{a-1} x_2^{1-a}}{(1-a) A x_1^a x_2^{-a}} TRS=−∂x2​∂f​∂x1​∂f​​=−(1−a)Ax1a​x2−a​aAx1a−1​x21−a​​

Simplifying:
TRS=−a1−a⋅x2x1 \text{TRS} = -\frac{a}{1-a} \cdot \frac{x_2}{x_1} TRS=−1−aa​⋅x1​x2​​

Thus, for a Cobb-Douglas production function, the TRS is proportional to the ratio of inputs, scaled by the factor a1−a\frac{a}{1-a}1−aa​.

2. TRS for a CES (Constant Elasticity of Substitution) Production Function

The CES production function is:
y=[a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ]11−ρ y = \left[ a_1 x_1^{\rho} + a_2 x_2^{\rho} \right]^{\frac{1}{1-\rho}} y=[a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​]1−ρ1​

The partial derivatives are:
∂y∂x1=1(1−ρ)(a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ−1⋅a1⋅ρ⋅x1ρ−1 \frac{\partial y}{\partial x_1} = \frac{1}{(1 - \rho)} \left( a_1 x_1^{\rho} + a_2 x_2^{\rho} \right)^{\frac{1}{\rho} - 1} \cdot a_1 \cdot \rho \cdot x_1^{\rho - 1} ∂x1​∂y​=(1−ρ)1​(a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​−1⋅a1​⋅ρ⋅x1ρ−1​

∂y∂x2=1(1−ρ)(a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ−1⋅a2⋅ρ⋅x2ρ−1 \frac{\partial y}{\partial x_2} = \frac{1}{(1 - \rho)} \left( a_1 x_1^{\rho} + a_2 x_2^{\rho} \right)^{\frac{1}{\rho} - 1} \cdot a_2 \cdot \rho \cdot x_2^{\rho - 1} ∂x2​∂y​=(1−ρ)1​(a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​−1⋅a2​⋅ρ⋅x2ρ−1​

dx2dx1=−a1a2⋅x1ρ−1x2ρ−1=−a1a2(x1x2)ρ−1 \frac{dx_2}{dx_1} = - \frac{a_1}{a_2} \cdot \frac{x_1^{\rho - 1}}{x_2^{\rho - 1}} = - \frac{a_1}{a_2} \left( \frac{x_1}{x_2} \right)^{\rho - 1} dx1​dx2​​=−a2​a1​​⋅x2ρ−1​x1ρ−1​​=−a2​a1​​(x2​x1​​)ρ−1

The TRS for the CES production function is:
TRS=−∂f∂x1∂f∂x2=−a1x1ρ−1a2x2ρ−1 \text{TRS} = -\frac{ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} }{ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} } = -\frac{ a_1 x_1^{\rho-1} }{ a_2 x_2^{\rho-1} } TRS=−∂x2​∂f​∂x1​∂f​​=−a2​x2ρ−1​a1​x1ρ−1​​

Simplifying:
TRS=−a1a2⋅(x1x2)ρ−1 \text{TRS} = -\frac{a_1}{a_2} \cdot \left( \frac{x_1}{x_2} \right)^{\rho-1} TRS=−a2​a1​​⋅(x2​x1​​)ρ−1

3. TRS for Perfect Substitutes

The production function for perfect substitutes is:
y=a1x1+a2x2 y = a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 y=a1​x1​+a2​x2​

In this case, the TRS is constant, as the inputs can be substituted at a constant rate. The partial derivatives are:
∂f∂x1=a1 \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} = a_1 ∂x1​∂f​=a1​
∂f∂x2=a2 \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} = a_2 ∂x2​∂f​=a2​

Thus, the TRS is:
TRS=−a1a2 \text{TRS} = -\frac{a_1}{a_2} TRS=−a2​a1​​

This implies that the two inputs are perfect substitutes for each other at the rate a1a2\frac{a_1}{a_2}a2​a1​​.

4. TRS for Perfect Complements

For perfect complements, the production function is:
y=min⁡(a1x1,a2x2) y = \min \left( a_1 x_1, a_2 x_2 \right) y=min(a1​x1​,a2​x2​)

In this case, the function is not differentiable, as the inputs must be used in fixed proportions. Therefore, we cannot use calculus to find the TRS.

However, we can infer the TRS based on the behavior of the inputs:

  • If a1x1>a2x2a_1 x_1 > a_2 x_2a1​x1​>a2​x2​, then TRS = ∞\infty∞, meaning no substitution is possible.
  • If a1x1=a2x2a_1 x_1 = a_2 x_2a1​x1​=a2​x2​, then TRS is undefined, as the inputs must be used in fixed proportions.
  • If a1x1<a2x2a_1 x_1 < a_2 x_2a1​x1​<a2​x2​, then TRS = 0, indicating that only one input can be increased without increasing the other.

Thus, for perfect complements, the TRS is either 0, infinity, or undefined depending on the combination of inputs.

Conclusion:

The Technical Rate of Substitution (TRS) captures the trade-off between inputs required to maintain the same level of output. Its derivation depends on the form of the production function, and its value can vary widely, from a simple ratio (as in Cobb-Douglas) to being undefined (as in perfect complements).

Elasticity of Substitution

The Technical Rate of Substitution (TRS) measures the slope of the isoquant, while the Elasticity of Substitution measures the curvature of the isoquant.

Definition:

The Elasticity of Substitution is defined as the percentage change in the ratio of factor inputs divided by the percentage change in the TRS, while keeping the output constant.

Mathematically, the Elasticity of Substitution (σ\sigmaσ) is expressed as:
σ=d(x2/x1)/(x2/x1)d(TRS)/TRS \sigma = \frac{d(x_2 / x_1)/(x_2/x_1)}{d(\text{TRS}) / \text{TRS}} σ=d(TRS)/TRSd(x2​/x1​)/(x2​/x1​)​

Where:

  • d(x2/x1)d(x_2 / x_1)d(x2​/x1​) represents the change in the ratio of factor inputs.
  • d(TRS)d(\text{TRS})d(TRS) represents the change in the TRS (the slope of the isoquant).

Intuitive Explanation:

The Elasticity of Substitution is a natural measure of the curvature of the isoquant. It captures how the ratio of factor inputs (x2/x1x_2 / x_1x2​/x1​) changes as the slope of the isoquant (TRS) changes.

  • If a small change in the slope (TRS) leads to a large change in the factor input ratio, the isoquant is relatively flat, and the elasticity (σ\sigmaσ) is large.
  • Conversely, if the isoquant is more curved, the elasticity (σ\sigmaσ) is lower, indicating that larger changes in TRS result in smaller changes in the input ratio.

Thus, σ\sigmaσ represents the sensitivity of the input mix to changes in the slope of the isoquant.

The formula for σ\sigmaσ is:
σ=%change in input mix (factor ratio)%change in slope (TRS) \sigma = \frac{\% \text{change in input mix (factor ratio)}}{\% \text{change in slope (TRS)}} σ=%change in slope (TRS)%change in input mix (factor ratio)​

Key Insights:

  • The more curved the isoquant, the lower the elasticity of substitution (σ\sigmaσ).
  • For any production technology, as σ→∞\sigma \to \inftyσ→∞, we approach the case of perfect substitutability between the factors of production.
  • As σ→0\sigma \to 0σ→0, we approach the case of no substitutability between factors (e.g., perfect complements).

Intuitive Interpretation of σ\sigmaσ:

  • If σ\sigmaσ is very high, even a small change in the TRS will lead to a large change in the input ratio. In this case, the factors must be very good substitutes.
  • If σ\sigmaσ is low, large percentage changes in the TRS result in minimal changes in the factor ratio. This implies that the factors are needed in fixed proportions and are not easily substitutable.

Elasticity of Substitution (σ\sigmaσ) Formula:

The general formula for σ\sigmaσ is:
σ=dln⁡(x2x1)dln⁡(TRS) \sigma = \frac{d \ln \left( \frac{x_2}{x_1} \right)}{d \ln (\text{TRS})} σ=dln(TRS)dln(x1​x2​​)​

This expression represents the ratio of the logarithmic change in the input mix (x2/x1x_2 / x_1x2​/x1​) to the logarithmic change in the TRS.

Examples:

1. Elasticity of Substitution for Cobb-Douglas Production Function:

For a Cobb-Douglas production function, the TRS is:
TRS=−a1−a⋅x2x1 \text{TRS} = \frac{-a}{1-a} \cdot \frac{x_2}{x_1} TRS=1−a−a​⋅x1​x2​​

Taking the logarithm of both sides:
ln⁡(TRS)=−ln⁡(a1−a)+ln⁡(x2x1) \ln(\text{TRS}) = -\ln\left(\frac{a}{1-a}\right) + \ln\left(\frac{x_2}{x_1}\right) ln(TRS)=−ln(1−aa​)+ln(x1​x2​​)

Thus, the elasticity of substitution (σ\sigmaσ) is:
σ=dln⁡(x2x1)dln⁡(TRS)=1 \sigma = \frac{d \ln \left( \frac{x_2}{x_1} \right)}{d \ln (\text{TRS})} = 1 σ=dln(TRS)dln(x1​x2​​)​=1

This shows that for a Cobb-Douglas production function, the elasticity of substitution is constant and equal to 1, implying that the inputs are substitutable but not perfect substitutes.

2. Elasticity of Substitution for CES Production Function:

TRS=−a1a2⋅(x1x2)ρ−1 \text{TRS} = -\frac{a_1}{a_2} \cdot \left( \frac{x_1}{x_2} \right)^{\rho - 1} TRS=−a2​a1​​⋅(x2​x1​​)ρ−1

Take the Logarithm of the TRS

Now, take the natural logarithm of both sides of the TRS equation:

ln⁡(TRS)=ln⁡(−a1a2⋅(x1x2)ρ−1) \ln(\text{TRS}) = \ln\left(-\frac{a_1}{a_2} \cdot \left( \frac{x_1}{x_2} \right)^{\rho - 1}\right) ln(TRS)=ln(−a2​a1​​⋅(x2​x1​​)ρ−1)

Using logarithmic properties, split this into two parts:

ln⁡(TRS)=ln⁡(a1a2)+(ρ−1)ln⁡(x1x2) \ln(\text{TRS}) = \ln\left(\frac{a_1}{a_2}\right) + (\rho - 1) \ln\left(\frac{x_1}{x_2}\right) ln(TRS)=ln(a2​a1​​)+(ρ−1)ln(x2​x1​​)

Since (ln⁡(−a1a2)=ln⁡(a1a2))( \ln(-\frac{a_1}{a_2}) = \ln\left(\frac{a_1}{a_2}\right) )(ln(−a2​a1​​)=ln(a2​a1​​)) (as the logarithm of a negative number isn’t defined for real values, we’ll handle it assuming it refers to magnitude):

ln⁡(TRS)=ln⁡(a1a2)+(ρ−1)ln⁡(x1x2) \ln(\text{TRS}) = \ln\left(\frac{a_1}{a_2}\right) + (\rho - 1) \ln\left(\frac{x_1}{x_2}\right) ln(TRS)=ln(a2​a1​​)+(ρ−1)ln(x2​x1​​)

Define Elasticity of Substitution

Elasticity of substitution (σ)( \sigma )(σ) is defined as the percentage change in the ratio of inputs divided by the percentage change in the TRS:

σ=dln⁡(x2x1)dln⁡(TRS) \sigma = \frac{d \ln \left( \frac{x_2}{x_1} \right)}{d \ln(\text{TRS})} σ=dln(TRS)dln(x1​x2​​)​

Using the equation for (ln⁡(TRS))( \ln(\text{TRS}) )(ln(TRS)), differentiate both sides with respect to (ln⁡(x2x1))( \ln\left( \frac{x_2}{x_1} \right) )(ln(x1​x2​​)):

dln⁡(TRS)dln⁡(x2x1)=ρ−1 \frac{d \ln(\text{TRS})}{d \ln\left( \frac{x_2}{x_1} \right)} = \rho - 1 dln(x1​x2​​)dln(TRS)​=ρ−1

Solve for (σ)( \sigma )(σ)

Now, the elasticity of substitution (σ)( \sigma )(σ) is the inverse of this derivative:

σ=11−ρ \sigma = \frac{1}{1 - \rho} σ=1−ρ1​

Thus, for the CES production function, the elasticity of substitution is:

σ=11−ρ \sigma = \frac{1}{1 - \rho} σ=1−ρ1​

The parameter ρ\rhoρ determines the degree of substitutability between the inputs. As ρ→1\rho \to 1ρ→1, the elasticity of substitution approaches infinity, indicating perfect substitutes. As ρ→−∞\rho \to -\inftyρ→−∞, the elasticity approaches zero, indicating perfect complements.

Conclusion:

The Elasticity of Substitution is a crucial concept in understanding how easily inputs in a production function can be substituted for one another. It provides a deeper insight into the curvature of the isoquant, complementing the TRS, which only measures the slope.
For example:

  • A Cobb-Douglas production function has a constant elasticity of substitution equal to 1.
  • A CES production function can have a varying elasticity, depending on the value of the parameter ρ\rhoρ.

Please refer to the CES production function example on page 19 (Figure 1.8) in the Textbook for a graphical representation of this concept.

Returns to Scale

The concept of Returns to Scale (RTS) refers to how the output of a production process changes when all inputs are scaled up or down by the same proportion. There are three main types of returns to scale:

1. Constant Returns to Scale (CRS):

A technology exhibits Constant Returns to Scale (CRS) if, when all inputs are multiplied by a scalar factor ttt, the output is also multiplied by ttt. Mathematically, a production function (f(x1,x2,…,xn))(f(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n) )(f(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)) exhibits CRS if either of the following conditions is satisfied:

  1. f(tx)=tf(x)f(tx) = t f(x)f(tx)=tf(x) for all t>0t > 0t>0, where xxx represents the vector of input quantities.
  2. The production function is homogeneous of degree 1, meaning that scaling inputs by a factor ttt scales the output by the same factor.

But is CRS always a reasonable assumption?

  • Not always. It may be possible to scale up production processes, but scaling down is often not trivial. Scaling down could result in hitting the minimum scale of production, beyond which further reduction may not be economically viable.

    • For example, scaling up by integer multiples is possible, but scaling down may hit a limit, where production becomes inefficient.

  • Also, while scaling up, it’s possible to encounter increasing efficiencies in certain production processes. For example, doubling all inputs might lead to more than double the output.

Example: Oil Pipeline

Consider a firm building an oil pipeline between two points, say A and B. If we double all inputs (such as materials, labor, etc.), the output (oil transported) might more than double. This happens because:

  • The surface area of the pipeline increases by a factor of 2.
  • But the volume of oil transported increases by a factor of 4, indicating Increasing Returns to Scale (IRS).

2. Increasing Returns to Scale (IRS):

A production function exhibits Increasing Returns to Scale (IRS) if, when all inputs are multiplied by a scalar t>1t > 1t>1, the output increases by more than ttt. Mathematically:
f(tx)>tf(x)for allt>1 f(tx) > t f(x) \quad \text{for all} \quad t > 1 f(tx)>tf(x)for allt>1

Example: The pipeline scenario discussed above is an example of IRS, where doubling the inputs leads to more than double the output.

Another way CRS might be violated is when certain inputs cannot be replicated, like agricultural land or specific natural resources, leading to IRS.

3. Decreasing Returns to Scale (DRS):

A production function exhibits Decreasing Returns to Scale (DRS) if, when all inputs are multiplied by a scalar t>1t > 1t>1, the output increases by less than ttt. Mathematically:
f(tx)<tf(x)for allt>1 f(tx) < t f(x) \quad \text{for all} \quad t > 1 f(tx)<tf(x)for allt>1

DRS typically arises when certain inputs are not easily replicable, such as specialized labor or land, leading to restricted production possibilities.

Proving Decreasing Returns to Scale:

Suppose we have a constant returns to scale (CRS) production function but face constraints due to fixed inputs. We can represent this by introducing a mythical input zzz and redefine the production function.

Let’s define a new production function F(x,z)F(x, z)F(x,z) such that:
F(x,z)=zf(xz) F(x, z) = z f \left( \frac{x}{z} \right) F(x,z)=zf(zx​)

This new function F(x,z)F(x, z)F(x,z) exhibits CRS. Mathematically, it holds that:
F(tx,tz)=tzf(txtz)=tzf(xz)=tF(x,z) F(tx, tz) = tz f \left( \frac{tx}{tz} \right) = t z f \left( \frac{x}{z} \right) = t F(x, z) F(tx,tz)=tzf(tztx​)=tzf(zx​)=tF(x,z)

Hence, the original DRS function f(x)f(x)f(x) can be seen as a restricted CRS function F(x,z)F(x, z)F(x,z) when z=1z = 1z=1.

Examples of Returns to Scale:

1. CES Production Function:

Consider a CES production function:
f(x1,x2)=(a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ f(x_1, x_2) = \left( a_1 x_1^\rho + a_2 x_2^\rho \right)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} f(x1​,x2​)=(a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​

For this function, the output when inputs are scaled by ttt is:
f(tx1,tx2)=(a1(tx1)ρ+a2(tx2)ρ)1ρ=t(a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ=tf(x1,x2) f(t x_1, t x_2) = \left( a_1 (t x_1)^\rho + a_2 (t x_2)^\rho \right)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} = t \left( a_1 x_1^\rho + a_2 x_2^\rho \right)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} = t f(x_1, x_2) f(tx1​,tx2​)=(a1​(tx1​)ρ+a2​(tx2​)ρ)ρ1​=t(a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​=tf(x1​,x2​)

Thus, this production function exhibits Constant Returns to Scale (CRS).

2. Decreasing Returns to Scale:

A simple production function like:
f(x1,x2)=x1α+x2βwhereα+β<1 f(x_1, x_2) = x_1^\alpha + x_2^\beta \quad \text{where} \quad \alpha + \beta < 1 f(x1​,x2​)=x1α​+x2β​whereα+β<1

When inputs are scaled by ttt, we get:
f(tx1,tx2)=(tx1)α+(tx2)β=tαx1α+tβx2β f(t x_1, t x_2) = (t x_1)^\alpha + (t x_2)^\beta = t^\alpha x_1^\alpha + t^\beta x_2^\beta f(tx1​,tx2​)=(tx1​)α+(tx2​)β=tαx1α​+tβx2β​

Since α+β<1\alpha + \beta < 1α+β<1, the function exhibits Decreasing Returns to Scale (DRS) because:
f(tx1,tx2)<tf(x1,x2) f(t x_1, t x_2) < t f(x_1, x_2) f(tx1​,tx2​)<tf(x1​,x2​)

3. Isoquant Shapes for Returns to Scale:

The shape of isoquants also provides insight into the type of returns to scale. For example:

  • IRS Isoquant: Isoquants are more spaced out as output increases, reflecting increasing efficiency as inputs scale up.
  • DRS Isoquant: Isoquants become closer as output increases, reflecting diminishing returns as inputs scale up.
  • CRS Isoquant: Isoquants maintain consistent spacing, indicating constant returns as inputs scale.

These characteristics illustrate how the shape of isoquants changes based on the type of returns to scale exhibited by the production function.

ELASTICITY OF SCALE

Elasticity of scale measures the percentage increase in output due to a one percent increase in all inputs, i.e., due to an increase in the scale of operations. Let’s begin by defining the production function.

Given a production function y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x), let ttt be a positive scalar used to represent a scaling factor for all inputs. We are interested in how the output y(t)y(t)y(t) changes when all inputs are scaled by a factor of ttt.

Let y(t)=f(tx)y(t) = f(tx)y(t)=f(tx), where (tx)( tx )(tx) represents the scaled inputs.

Scale of Operations:

  • When t=1t = 1t=1, it represents the current scale of operations.
  • When t>1t > 1t>1, it represents scaling up all inputs by a factor of ttt.
  • When t<1t < 1t<1, it represents scaling down all inputs by a factor of ttt.

The elasticity of scale, denoted as e(x)e(x)e(x), is defined as:

e(x)=(dy(t)dt⋅ty(t))∣t=1 e(x) = \left( \frac{d y(t)}{d t} \cdot \frac{t}{y(t)} \right) \bigg|_{t=1} e(x)=(dtdy(t)​⋅y(t)t​)∣∣​t=1​

This expression helps us analyze how the production technology behaves as we scale inputs. Specifically:

  • If e(x)=1e(x) = 1e(x)=1, the technology exhibits constant returns to scale (CRS).
  • If e(x)<1e(x) < 1e(x)<1, the technology exhibits decreasing returns to scale (DRS).
  • If e(x)>1e(x) > 1e(x)>1, the technology exhibits increasing returns to scale (IRS).

Example:

Let’s consider an example production function:

y(t)=(a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ y(t) = (a_1 x_1^\rho + a_2 x_2^\rho)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} y(t)=(a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​

Now, we calculate the derivative of y(t)y(t)y(t) with respect to ttt to determine the elasticity of scale. Taking the derivative:

dy(t)dt=(ddt((a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ)) \frac{d y(t)}{d t} = \left( \frac{d}{d t} \left( (a_1 x_1^\rho + a_2 x_2^\rho)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} \right) \right) dtdy(t)​=(dtd​((a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​))

Evaluating this at t=1t = 1t=1:

e(x)=(ddt((a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ)⋅t(a1x1ρ+a2x2ρ)1ρ)∣t=1 e(x) = \left( \frac{d}{d t} \left( (a_1 x_1^\rho + a_2 x_2^\rho)^{\frac{1}{\rho}} \right) \cdot \frac{t}{(a_1 x_1^\rho + a_2 x_2^\rho)^{\frac{1}{\rho}}} \right) \bigg|_{t=1} e(x)=(dtd​((a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​)⋅(a1​x1ρ​+a2​x2ρ​)ρ1​t​)∣∣​t=1​

Thus, if (a1+a2)=1(a_1 + a_2) = 1(a1​+a2​)=1, we have CRS. If (a1+a2)<1(a_1 + a_2) < 1(a1​+a2​)<1, we have DRS, and if (a1+a2)>1(a_1 + a_2) > 1(a1​+a2​)>1, we have IRS.

Elasticity of Scale for a Single Input:

Elasticity of scale for a single input is the ratio of marginal product (MP) to average product (AP). We will now prove this.

We begin by defining the elasticity of scale, e(x)e(x)e(x), as:

e(x)=df(tx)dt⋅tf(tx)∣t=1 e(x) = \frac{d f(tx)}{d t} \cdot \frac{t}{f(tx)} \bigg|_{t=1} e(x)=dtdf(tx)​⋅f(tx)t​∣∣​t=1​

This represents how output changes in response to a uniform scaling of all inputs by ttt. The expression can be rewritten as:

e(x)=df(tx)dt⋅tf(tx)∣t=1 e(x) = \frac{\frac{d f(tx)}{d t} \cdot t}{f(tx)} \bigg|_{t=1} e(x)=f(tx)dtdf(tx)​⋅t​∣∣​t=1​

Next, we differentiate the function f(tx)f(tx)f(tx) with respect to ttt:

df(tx)dt=∂f(tx)∂(tx)⋅∂(tx)∂t \frac{d f(tx)}{d t} = \frac{\partial f(tx)}{\partial (tx)} \cdot \frac{\partial (tx)}{\partial t} dtdf(tx)​=∂(tx)∂f(tx)​⋅∂t∂(tx)​

Substitute this into the elasticity expression:

e(x)=∂f(tx)∂(tx)⋅∂(tx)∂t⋅tf(tx)∣t=1 e(x) = \frac{\frac{\partial f(tx)}{\partial (tx)} \cdot \frac{\partial (tx)}{\partial t} \cdot t}{f(tx)} \bigg|_{t=1} e(x)=f(tx)∂(tx)∂f(tx)​⋅∂t∂(tx)​⋅t​∣∣​t=1​

Since ∂(tx)∂t=x\frac{\partial (tx)}{\partial t} = x∂t∂(tx)​=x, the expression becomes:

e(x)=∂f(tx)∂(tx)⋅x⋅tf(tx)∣t=1 e(x) = \frac{\frac{\partial f(tx)}{\partial (tx)} \cdot x \cdot t}{f(tx)} \bigg|_{t=1} e(x)=f(tx)∂(tx)∂f(tx)​⋅x⋅t​∣∣​t=1​

Evaluating this at t=1t = 1t=1, we get:

e(x)=∂f(x)∂x⋅xf(x) e(x) = \frac{\frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x} \cdot x}{f(x)} e(x)=f(x)∂x∂f(x)​⋅x​

This expression represents the ratio of marginal product (MPx)( MP_x )(MPx​) to average product (APx)( AP_x )(APx​). Thus, we can conclude:

e(x)=MPxAPx e(x) = \frac{MP_x}{AP_x} e(x)=APx​MPx​​

Hence, the elasticity of scale for a single input is the ratio of the marginal product to the average product.

HOMOGENEOUS AND HOMOTHETIC TECHNOLOGIES

A function f(x)f(x)f(x) is homogeneous of degree kkk if:

f(tx)=tk⋅f(x)for all t>0 f(tx) = t^k \cdot f(x) \quad \text{for all} \, t > 0 f(tx)=tk⋅f(x)for allt>0

This property describes how a production function responds to proportional changes in all inputs. There are two important special cases of homogeneity:

  • Homogeneous of degree 0:
    f(tx)=f(x) f(tx) = f(x) f(tx)=f(x)
    This indicates that the output remains unchanged when all inputs are scaled by a factor ttt.

  • Homogeneous of degree 1:
    f(tx)=t⋅f(x) f(tx) = t \cdot f(x) f(tx)=t⋅f(x)
    This represents constant returns to scale (CRS), meaning if all inputs are scaled by a factor ttt, the output is scaled by the same factor. Thus, CRS technology is only valid for production functions that are homogeneous of degree 1.

Homothetic Functions

A homothetic function is defined as a monotonic transformation of a function that is homogeneous of degree 1.

Definition:

Let g:R→Rg: \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}g:R→R be a strictly increasing function, which is called a positive monotonic transformation. That is, if x>yx > yx>y, then g(x)>g(y)g(x) > g(y)g(x)>g(y).

A function f(x)f(x)f(x) is homothetic if there exists a homogeneous function h(x)h(x)h(x) of degree 1, such that:

f(x)=g(h(x)) f(x) = g(h(x)) f(x)=g(h(x))

In this case, g(.)g(.)g(.) is a monotonic transformation. For example, let h(x)h(x)h(x) be homogeneous of degree 1. Then f(x)f(x)f(x) is homothetic if and only if g(.)g(.)g(.) is monotonic.

Example:

Suppose h(x)=2yh(x) = 2yh(x)=2y, where x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ are inputs. Then, for a homothetic function:

f(x)=g(2y) f(x) = g(2y) f(x)=g(2y)

This means the output f(x)f(x)f(x) is a transformed version of a homogeneous function of degree 1.

Why Study Homogeneous and Homothetic Functions?

  1. Homogeneous Functions:

    • Many well-behaved production functions in economics are homogeneous of degree 1, which is directly related to CRS technology.
    • Homogeneous functions of degree 1 imply that output scales proportionally with inputs, which is a crucial assumption in many economic models.

  2. Homothetic Functions:

    • Homothetic functions allow for flexibility because they include a monotonic transformation of a CRS technology.
    • These transformations enable us to measure output in different units (e.g., converting kilograms to pounds) without altering the fundamental relationship between inputs and outputs.

For instance, changing from kilograms to pounds is a simple monotonic transformation. However, if we apply a more complex transformation, such as squaring or taking the square root of the output, the output may change non-linearly.

In the figures, we can describe the behavior of isoquants for homogeneous and homothetic functions as follows:

  • Homogeneous Isoquants:

    • If the production function is homogeneous, doubling the inputs results in output doubling. This implies constant returns to scale (CRS) when the function is homogeneous of degree 1.
    • Hence, homogeneous isoquants represent a situation where scaling up all inputs by the same factor leads to an exact doubling of output.

  • Homothetic Isoquants:

    • If the production function is homothetic, increasing the inputs does lead to an increase in output, but the change is not necessarily proportional.
    • Homothetic isoquants, therefore, show that output has increased, but the magnitude of the increase is ambiguous and depends on the specific monotonic transformation applied.

Formalization

Let us now formalize the differences between homogeneous and homothetic functions:

Homogeneous Function

If f(x)f(x)f(x) is homogeneous of degree kkk, then for any scalar t>0t > 0t>0:

f(tx)=tk⋅f(x) f(tx) = t^k \cdot f(x) f(tx)=tk⋅f(x)

This means that scaling the inputs xxx by ttt will result in the output scaling by tkt^ktk. For example, if k=1k = 1k=1, this implies constant returns to scale (CRS), where:

f(tx)=t⋅f(x) f(tx) = t \cdot f(x) f(tx)=t⋅f(x)

In particular, if we take two different input levels txtxtx and tx′tx'tx′, then the output scales accordingly:

f(tx)=tyandf(tx′)=ty′ f(tx) = ty \quad \text{and} \quad f(tx') = ty' f(tx)=tyandf(tx′)=ty′

where yyy and y′y'y′ are the output levels corresponding to the inputs xxx and x′x'x′, respectively. In this case, output scales by the same factor as the inputs.

Homothetic Function

If g(x)g(x)g(x) is homothetic, then increasing the inputs xxx by a factor ttt and t′t't′ leads to an increase in output. However, unlike in the case of homogeneous functions, the output does not necessarily scale proportionally with the inputs.

This means:

g(tx)andg(tx′) g(tx) \quad \text{and} \quad g(tx') g(tx)andg(tx′)

lead to an increase in output, but the increase is not exactly proportional to the increase in inputs as it would be for a homogeneous function. This distinction arises because a homothetic function involves a monotonic transformation of a homogeneous function of degree 1.

Thus, a homothetic function provides a way to measure output so that it behaves like a CRS function.

Elasticity of Scale and TRS

Both homogeneous and homothetic functions have the property that the technical rate of substitution (TRS) is independent of the scale of production. This is a crucial property for analyzing how inputs can be substituted for one another without affecting the output level.

Proof:

Consider a function that is homogeneous of degree kkk. By definition, we have:

f(tx1,tx2,…,txn)=tk⋅f(x1,x2,…,xn) f(tx_1, tx_2, \dots, tx_n) = t^k \cdot f(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n) f(tx1​,tx2​,…,txn​)=tk⋅f(x1​,x2​,…,xn​)

Differentiating both sides with respect to ttt, we get:

∂f(tx)∂t=tk⋅∂f(x)∂x \frac{\partial f(tx)}{\partial t} = t^k \cdot \frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x} ∂t∂f(tx)​=tk⋅∂x∂f(x)​

Since the partial derivative of f(x)f(x)f(x) with respect to xix_ixi​ is homogeneous of degree k−1k-1k−1, we have:

∂f(tx)∂xi=tk−1⋅∂f(x)∂xi \frac{\partial f(tx)}{\partial x_i} = t^{k-1} \cdot \frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x_i} ∂xi​∂f(tx)​=tk−1⋅∂xi​∂f(x)​

It follows that for a homogeneous function of degree kkk, its partial derivative is homogeneous of degree k−1k-1k−1.

Thus, the TRS, which is the ratio of partial derivatives, is homogeneous of degree 0. In other words, the TRS is independent of the scale of production, as it depends only on the ratio of inputs, not their absolute levels.

Summary:

  • Homogeneous functions describe production processes that scale proportionally with inputs.
  • Homothetic functions generalize this idea by allowing for a monotonic transformation of a CRS function, enabling flexibility in measuring output.
  • Both functions have a TRS that is independent of scale, which simplifies the analysis of input substitution in production.

Chapter 2 - Microeconomics (Profit Maximization)

What is Profit?

In economics, profit is defined as the difference between the revenue a firm receives and the costs it incurs during the production of goods and services.

We have already learned that economic cost is different from the cost as defined in accountancy. In accountancy, cost represents anything the business has explicitly paid for, and we can calculate accounting costs by simply examining the company’s balance sheet. However, economic costs represent a “what if” scenario for your business. These costs include both explicit costs (like those in accountancy) and implicit costs.

Implicit costs refer to those costs that are not recorded in the ledger but represent the opportunity cost of using resources. For instance, if a person owns a business, they forego the salary they could have earned working elsewhere. This foregone salary is considered an implicit cost of running the current business.

Profit, Revenue, and Cost Functions

Now, both the revenue and costs of a firm depend on the decisions or actions taken by the firm. These actions can include production activities, purchasing inputs, advertising expenses, innovation efforts, etc.

Suppose we write these actions as a1,a2,…,ana_1, a_2, \ldots, a_na1​,a2​,…,an​.

Revenue function:
R(a1,a2,…,an) R(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n) R(a1​,a2​,…,an​)

Cost function:
C(a1,a2,…,an) C(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n) C(a1​,a2​,…,an​)

A fundamental assumption in economic analysis is that a firm acts to maximize its profits. We can express the profit maximization condition as:

π=max⁡(R(a1,a2,…,an)−C(a1,a2,…,an)) \pi = \max \left( R(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n) - C(a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n) \right) π=max(R(a1​,a2​,…,an​)−C(a1​,a2​,…,an​))

Basic Principles of Profit Maximization

Even at this broad level of generality, two fundamental principles of profit maximization emerge.

A simple application of calculus shows that the optimal set of conditions for profit maximization can be written as follows:

First-order condition for maximization:
∂R(a∗)∂ai−∂C(a∗)∂ai=0for i=1,…,n \frac{\partial R(a^*)}{\partial a_i} - \frac{\partial C(a^*)}{\partial a_i} = 0 \quad \text{for } i = 1, \ldots, n ∂ai​∂R(a∗)​−∂ai​∂C(a∗)​=0for i=1,…,n

This implies:
∂R(a∗)∂ai=∂C(a∗)∂aifor i=1,…,n \frac{\partial R(a^*)}{\partial a_i} = \frac{\partial C(a^*)}{\partial a_i} \quad \text{for } i = 1, \ldots, n ∂ai​∂R(a∗)​=∂ai​∂C(a∗)​for i=1,…,n

Interpretation

This condition suggests that profit is maximized when the marginal revenue (MR) from an additional unit of aia_iai​ equals the marginal cost (MC). The intuition behind this is:

  • If MR>MCMR > MCMR>MC, the firm should keep increasing aia_iai​ to increase profits.
  • If MR<MCMR < MCMR<MC, the firm should decrease aia_iai​ to prevent a loss in profits.
  • If MR=MCMR = MCMR=MC, the firm is at the optimal point where profits are maximized, and any further change in aia_iai​ will not improve profits.

Thus, marginal revenue equals marginal cost is the key condition for profit maximization.

Applications of the First Condition

This fundamental condition can be applied in several ways:

  • The firm can decide the quantity of output to produce using this condition.
  • The firm can also determine the amount of labor to hire based on this condition.

Second Fundamental Condition of Profit Maximization

The second fundamental condition is the condition of long-run profits. If two firms have identical revenue and cost functions, then in the long run, they cannot have equal profits. Why? Because the firm earning lower profit can imitate the actions of the other firm and claim the same amount of profit.

To apply these conditions in a more structured manner, let us examine the revenue and cost components more carefully.

Revenue and Costs

  • Revenue: This is how much a firm sells, determined by the price of each unit sold.
  • Costs: This is how much a firm incurs, determined by the price of each unit of input used.

When the firm is maximizing its profit, at a more fundamental level, it is:

  1. Choosing what prices to charge for its output.
  2. Deciding what levels of output and inputs it wishes to use and pay for.

Of course, it cannot set prices unilaterally.

Constraints in Determining Optimal Policy

While determining its optimal policy, the firm faces two kinds of constraints:

  • Technological constraints: These are constraints that concern the feasibility of the production plan.
  • Market constraints: These concern the effect of the actions of other agents on the firm, such as consumers, suppliers, and other firms.

When the firm decides on its optimal policy, it must take into account both of these constraints.

We will assume the simplest kind of market constraints—each firm takes the price of goods as given. Thus, the firm will choose the amount of output and inputs. We will study the optimal choice of production plans for the firm in a competitive environment.

Profit Maximization

We are trying to analyze a firm’s actions when the prices of output and inputs are given. Let PPP be a vector of prices for inputs and outputs of the firm—a row vector of prices with the first value being the price of the output good.

Profit Maximization Problem

The profit maximization problem can be expressed as:

π(P)=max⁡pys.t. y∈Y \pi(P) = \max py \quad \text{s.t. } y \in Y π(P)=maxpys.t. y∈Y

Where:

π(P)=Pq−wL−rk \pi(P) = Pq - wL - rk π(P)=Pq−wL−rk

The function π(P)\pi(P)π(P) represents the maximum profit as a function of the quantities, and this is called the profit function of the firm.

Restricted Profit Function

If we are considering a short-run maximization problem, a restricted profit function will be:

π∗(P,z)=max⁡pys.t. y∈Y(z) \pi^*(P, z) = \max py \quad \text{s.t. } y \in Y(z) π∗(P,z)=maxpys.t. y∈Y(z)

If the firm produces a single good, then:

πT(P,w)=pf(x) \pi^T(P, w) = p f(x) πT(P,w)=pf(x)

Where www is a column vector of non-negative input quantities and xxx is a vector of input prices.

Cost Function

The cost function can be expressed as:

C(w,y)=min⁡wxs.t. x∈V(y) C(w, y) = \min wx \quad \text{s.t. } x \in V(y) C(w,y)=minwxs.t. x∈V(y)

We can think of it as a form of restricted profit function since it applies to a particular level of output.

Restricted Cost Function

The restricted cost function is given by:

C(w,y,z)=min⁡wxs.t. (y,−x)∈Y(z) C(w, y, z) = \min wx \quad \text{s.t. } (y, - x) \in Y(z) C(w,y,z)=minwxs.t. (y,−x)∈Y(z)

The cost function gives the minimum cost of producing a level of output yyy when input prices are www.

Note: We do not consider the price of output as given in this formulation, so the firm is a price taker only in the input market, which is useful for monopoly markets.

First-Order Conditions (F.O.C)

For a single output, we have:

πT(P,w)=Pf(x)−wx \pi^T(P, w) = Pf(x) - wx πT(P,w)=Pf(x)−wx

The first-order condition is given by:

∂πT(P,W)∂x=P∂f(x∗)/∂xi−wi=0for i=1,…,n \frac{\partial \pi^T(P, W)}{\partial x} = P \partial f(x^*)/\partial x_i - w_i = 0 \quad \text{for } i = 1, \ldots, n ∂x∂πT(P,W)​=P∂f(x∗)/∂xi​−wi​=0for i=1,…,n

This implies:

PDf(x∗)=W P D f(x^*) = W PDf(x∗)=W

Value of Marginal Product

In vector notation:

PDf(x∗)=W P D f(x^*) = W PDf(x∗)=W

Df(x∗)=(∂f(x∗)∂x1,…,∂f(x∗)∂xn)D f(x^*) = \left( \frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_1}, \ldots, \frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_n} \right)Df(x∗)=(∂x1​∂f(x∗)​,…,∂xn​∂f(x∗)​)

W=(w1,w2,…,wn)W = (w_1, w_2, \ldots, w_n)W=(w1​,w2​,…,wn​)

"Value of marginal product equals price"

  • The first fundamental condition of profit maximizing action

Graphical Representation of F.O.C

Let the production possibility set be given by YYY. Since we are producing a single output, it can be presented as:

In this 2D case, profit can be expressed as:

π=py−wx \pi = py - wx π=py−wx

The isoprofit line in the (y,x)(y, x)(y,x) plane is a straight upward-sloping line with an intercept of πp\frac{\pi}{p}pπ​ and a slope of Wp\frac{W}{p}pW​.

Second-Order Conditions for Profit Maximization

A profit-maximizing firm wants to find a point on the production set with the maximum level of profits.

To ensure local concavity, the second derivative conditions must be satisfied:

∂2f(x∗)∂x2≤0 \frac{\partial^2 f(x^*)}{\partial x^2} \leq 0 ∂x2∂2f(x∗)​≤0

For a multiple input case, the matrix of the second derivatives of the production function must be negative semi-definite:

D2f(x∗)=(∂2f(x∗)∂xi∂xi) D^2 f(x^*) = \left(\frac{\partial^2 f(x^*)}{\partial x_i{\partial x_i}}\right) D2f(x∗)=(∂xi​∂xi​∂2f(x∗)​)

For AAA to be a semi-negative definite matrix, all principal minors A1,A2,…,AmA_1, A_2, \ldots, A_mA1​,A2​,…,Am​ must satisfy the following property: they alternate in signs beginning with a minus one. In other words, ∣Ai∣≤0|A_i| \leq 0∣Ai​∣≤0 for iii being odd and ∣Ai∣≥0|A_i| \geq 0∣Ai​∣≥0 for iii being even.

Profit Maximization Challenges

Factor Demand Function

The factor demand function gives us the optimal choice of inputs as a function of prices (P,w)(P, w)(P,w):

x(P,w) x(P, w) x(P,w)

Supply Function

The supply function expresses output as a function of the optimal input:

y(P,w)=f(x[P,w]) y(P, w) = f(x[P, w]) y(P,w)=f(x[P,w])

We assume that both the factor demand function and the firm supply function are well-defined and behave nicely. However, it is worth considering problems that may arise if they do not.

Issues with Technology

Technology may not be described by a differentiable production function, which affects the derivatives described above. For example, in the case of a Leontief production function, the calculus conditions derived above make sense only when the choice variables can be varied in an open neighborhood of the optimal choice. If some variables have a value of zero at the optimal choice, the calculus conditions may be inappropriate.

The necessary modifications to handle boundary solutions are not difficult to state. For example, if we constrain xxx to be non-negative in the maximization problem, the relevant first-order conditions (F.O.C.) become:

ρ∂k∂xi−ωi≤0 if xi=0\rho \frac{\partial k}{\partial x_i} - \omega_i \leq 0 \text{ if } x_i = 0ρ∂xi​∂k​−ωi​≤0 if xi​=0

ρ∂f∂xi−ωi=0 if xi>0\rho \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_i} - \omega_i = 0 \text{ if } x_i > 0ρ∂xi​∂f​−ωi​=0 if xi​>0
[Combined marginal profit from increasing xix_ixi​ must be non-positive]

Thus, the marginal profit from increasing xxx must be non-positive, leading to the Kuhn-Tucker conditions (to be revisited later).

No Profit-Maximizing Production Plan

There may exist cases where no profit-maximizing production plan is possible. For example, consider the production function:

f(x)=x f(x) = x f(x)=x

Then the profit function is:

π=P⋅fx−Wx \pi = P \cdot f{x} - Wx π=P⋅fx−Wx

The derivative of π\piπ with respect to xxx is always positive, meaning profit is ever-increasing. Thus, there is no maximum profit point.

Constant Returns to Scale (CRS)

If f(x)f(x)f(x) exhibits constant returns to scale (CRS), then:

π=P⋅f(x∗)−wx∗ \pi = P \cdot f(x^*) - wx^* π=P⋅f(x∗)−wx∗
∂π∂x=p−w>0\frac{\partial \pi}{\partial x} = p - w > 0∂x∂π​=p−w>0

If we scale up production by a factor t>1t>1t>1 profit will be:

Pf(tx∗)−wtx∗=tx∗>x∗ P f(tx^*) - wtx^* = tx^* > x^* Pf(tx∗)−wtx∗=tx∗>x∗

In this case, profits can be made larger, leading to unbounded profits and thus no maximal profit production plan will exist.

Profit Maximization with CRS

What if Pf(x∗)−w⋅x∗=0?Pf(x^*) - w \cdot x^* = 0?Pf(x∗)−w⋅x∗=0?  with CRS?\text{ with CRS?} with CRS?

If π(P,w)=0\pi(P, w) = 0π(P,w)=0 with CRS, and the firm is making a profit, then it is indifferent between all input choices. Therefore, the production plan may not be unique. If f(tx)f(tx)f(tx) yields the same profit level for various inputs, profit maximization is not possible.

If a CRS firm is making a profit, it is indifferent between all other input choices.

Formalizing the Profit Maximization Problem

Let us formalize the maximization problem using a single output:

π=Pf(x)−wx \pi = Pf(x) - wx π=Pf(x)−wx

The first-order condition (F.O.C.) is:

Pf′(x)−w=0 P f'(x) - w = 0 Pf′(x)−w=0

Second-Order Conditions (S.O.C.)

The second-order condition for profit maximization is:

1P⋅f′′(x(P,w))≤0 \frac{1}{P\cdot f'' (x(P,w))} \leq 0 P⋅f′′(x(P,w))1​≤0

Example: Profit Maximization for Cobb-Douglas Technology

Consider a Cobb-Douglas production function:

f(x)=xawhere a>0 f(x) = x^a \quad \text{where } a > 0 f(x)=xawhere a>0

The first-order condition becomes:

Paxa−1−w=0 P a x^{a-1} - w = 0 Paxa−1−w=0

The second-order condition is:

Pa(a−1)xa−2≤0 P a (a - 1) x^{a-2} \leq 0 Pa(a−1)xa−2≤0

For the second-order condition to be satisfied, we require ≤1\leq 1≤1.

Implications of Cobb-Douglas Technology

  1. If a<1a < 1a<1: The firm has a unique profit-maximizing production plan.
  2. If a=1a = 1a=1: Profit maximization is achievable, and the F.O.C. does not depend on aaa.
  3. If a>1a > 1a>1: The firm does not have a unique profit-maximizing production plan.

Deriving Factor Demand and Supply Functions

For a<1a < 1a<1, we can derive the factor demand function and the firm supply function using the first-order condition:

Paxa−1=w P a x^{a-1} = w Paxa−1=w

Thus, the factor demand function tells us how much input the firm will demand as a function of its own price, given other parameters:

Y(P,w)=f(x(P,w))=wa⋅paa−1 Y(P, w) = f(x(P, w)) = \frac{w}{a\cdot p}^\frac{a}{a-1} Y(P,w)=f(x(P,w))=a⋅pw​a−1a​

The firm supply function gives us information on the amount of output that the firm will be willing to produce as a function of the price of the output.

Finally, the profit function is given by:

π(P,W)=P⋅y(P,w)−w⋅x(P,w) \pi(P, W) = P \cdot y(P, w) - w \cdot x(P, w) π(P,W)=P⋅y(P,w)−w⋅x(P,w)
=w1−aa⋅wa⋅paa−1=w\frac{1-a}{a}\cdot \frac{w}{a\cdot p}^\frac{a}{a-1}=wa1−a​⋅a⋅pw​a−1a​

Properties of the Demand and Supply Function

  • Factor demand function: The factor demand function refers to the optimal choice of input as a function of prices.

  • Firm supply function: The firm supply function refers to the optimal choice of output as a function of prices.

How do we get these functions from the profit maximization solution?

These functions are derived from the profit maximization problem, which implies certain restrictions on the behavior of the demand and supply functions.

If we multiply all of the prices by some positive number ttt, the vector of factor input that maximizes profit π\piπ will not change.

Proof:

The profit function is defined as:

π=P⋅f(x)−w⋅x \pi = P \cdot f(x) - w \cdot x π=P⋅f(x)−w⋅x

where PPP is the output price, f(x)f(x)f(x) is the production function, www is the input price, and xxx is the quantity of input.

The first-order condition (F.O.C.) for profit maximization is given by:

P⋅f′(x)=w P \cdot f'(x) = w P⋅f′(x)=w

Now, consider multiplying all prices by a positive scalar ttt:

π=tP⋅f(x)−tw⋅x \pi = tP \cdot f(x) - tw \cdot x π=tP⋅f(x)−tw⋅x

The F.O.C. remains the same:

tP⋅f′(x)=tw tP \cdot f'(x) = tw tP⋅f′(x)=tw

Simplifying:

P⋅f′(x)=w P \cdot f'(x) = w P⋅f′(x)=w

This shows that the optimal input choice xi(P,w)x_i(P, w)xi​(P,w) is unaffected by scaling prices. Thus, we conclude:

xi(tP,tw)=xi(P,w) x_i(tP, tw) = x_i(P, w) xi​(tP,tw)=xi​(P,w)

This proves that factor demand functions are homogeneous of degree zero.

Implications:

This property is important because it provides a way to verify if an observed production plan is generated by a firm maximizing profits. Specifically, factor demand functions should be homogeneous of degree zero.

Practical Uses of This Property:

  1. Theoretical Examination:

    • We can use this property to make theoretical statements about how a profit-maximizing firm would respond to changes in its economic environment (e.g., changes in prices).

  2. Empirical Validation:

    • We can empirically test if a firm’s observed demand functions exhibit patterns consistent with profit maximization. For example, if prices double but the firm’s demand and supplies change, the firm is not a profit maximizer.

Example:

If a firm’s demand and supplies change when prices double without any other change, the firm is not a profit maximizer. This contradicts the property that demand functions should be homogeneous of degree zero.

How Do We Derive These Properties?

There are three main methods:

  1. First-order conditions (F.O.C.):

    • By examining the F.O.C. that characterize the firm’s optimal choices.

  2. Direct Examination of the Demand and Supply Functions:

    • By examining the maximizing properties of demand and supply functions directly.

  3. Properties of the Profit and Cost Functions:

    • By analyzing how profit and cost functions respond to changes in prices and other factors.

Comparative Static Analysis:

Comparative static analysis involves examining how optimal choices respond to changes in the economic environment. In particular, we are interested in the sensitivity of optimal choices to changes in one of the parameters of the model.

What is Comparative Static Analysis?

Comparative static analysis helps us understand how a firm’s optimal decisions (e.g., input choices, output levels) change in response to exogenous shocks to the model, such as changes in prices or technology.

Comparative Statics Using F.O.Cs

Let’s consider a firm that maximizes its profits with one output and one input. The profit maximization problem is formulated as follows:

π=Pf(x)−wx \pi = P f(x) - wx π=Pf(x)−wx

where PPP is the output price, f(x)f(x)f(x) is the production function, and www is the input price.

F.O.C. (First-Order Condition) of Profit Maximization:

The first-order condition (F.O.C.) for profit maximization is given by:

Pf′(x(P,w))−w=0 P f'(x(P, w)) - w = 0 Pf′(x(P,w))−w=0

Here, x(P,w)x(P, w)x(P,w) represents the equilibrium choice of the input xxx as a function of prices PPP and www. Therefore, x(P,w)x(P, w)x(P,w) is the factor demand function.

S.O.C. (Second-Order Condition):

The second-order condition (S.O.C.) ensures that the firm’s profit is maximized:

Pf′′(x(P,w))≤0 P f''(x(P, w)) \leq 0 Pf′′(x(P,w))≤0

This confirms that the profit function is concave, ensuring that the solution is a maximum.

Comparative Static Analysis:

Suppose we want to examine how x(P,w)x(P, w)x(P,w) changes when the input price www changes. This is where comparative static analysis comes into play.

We start by differentiating the F.O.C. with respect to www:

Pf′(x(P,w))−w=0 P f'(x(P, w)) - w = 0 Pf′(x(P,w))−w=0

Differentiating both sides with respect to www:

Pf′′(x(P,w))dx(P,w)dw−1=0 P f''(x(P, w)) \frac{dx(P, w)}{dw} - 1 = 0 Pf′′(x(P,w))dwdx(P,w)​−1=0

Rearranging this expression:

dx(P,w)dw=1Pf′′(x(P,w)) \frac{dx(P, w)}{dw} = \frac{1}{P f''(x(P, w))} dwdx(P,w)​=Pf′′(x(P,w))1​

Since f′′(x)≤0f''(x) \leq 0f′′(x)≤0 from the second-order condition, the sign of dx(P,w)dw\frac{dx(P, w)}{dw}dwdx(P,w)​ is negative. Thus, an increase in the price of the input reduces its demand, as expected.

This method gives us an explicit expression for how the demand for the input changes with respect to changes in its price, dxdw\frac{dx}{dw}dwdx​.

Comparative Static Analysis for Two Inputs:

Now, let’s extend the analysis to a case where the firm has one output and two inputs (x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​). For simplicity, we assume the price of the output, P=1P = 1P=1. The profit maximization problem becomes:

π=f(x1,x2)−w1x1−w2x2 \pi = f(x_1, x_2) - w_1 x_1 - w_2 x_2 π=f(x1​,x2​)−w1​x1​−w2​x2​

F.O.C. (First-Order Conditions) for Two Inputs:

The first-order conditions for maximizing profits with respect to x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ are:

∂f(x1,x2)∂x1=w1 \frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2)}{\partial x_1} = w_1 ∂x1​∂f(x1​,x2​)​=w1​

∂f(x1,x2)∂x2=w2 \frac{\partial f(x_1, x_2)}{\partial x_2} = w_2 ∂x2​∂f(x1​,x2​)​=w2​

These conditions give the optimal values of x1(w1,w2)x_1(w_1, w_2)x1​(w1​,w2​) and x2(w1,w2)x_2(w_1, w_2)x2​(w1​,w2​) that satisfy the profit-maximizing conditions.

The optimal values of x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ →\rightarrow→ x1(w1,w2)x_1(w_1, w_2)x1​(w1​,w2​) and x2(w1,w2)x_2(w_1, w_2)x2​(w1​,w2​) will always satisfy these F.O.C.s:

∂f(x1(w1,w2),x2(w1,w2))∂x1=w1 \frac{\partial f(x_1(w_1, w_2), x_2(w_1, w_2))}{\partial x_1} = w_1 ∂x1​∂f(x1​(w1​,w2​),x2​(w1​,w2​))​=w1​

∂f(x1(w1,w2),x2(w1,w2))∂x2=w2 \frac{\partial f(x_1(w_1, w_2), x_2(w_1, w_2))}{\partial x_2} = w_2 ∂x2​∂f(x1​(w1​,w2​),x2​(w1​,w2​))​=w2​

Comparative Statics for Two Inputs:

To see how the inputs x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ change with respect to changes in input prices, we differentiate the F.O.C.s with respect to w1w_1w1​. The differentiation of the first F.O.C. with respect to w1w_1w1​ yields:

f11(x1,x2)dx1dw1+f12(x1,x2)dx2dw1=1 f_{11}(x_1, x_2) \frac{dx_1}{dw_1} + f_{12}(x_1, x_2) \frac{dx_2}{dw_1} = 1 f11​(x1​,x2​)dw1​dx1​​+f12​(x1​,x2​)dw1​dx2​​=1

For the second F.O.C., differentiation with respect to w1w_1w1​ gives:

f21(x1,x2)dx1dw1+f22(x1,x2)dx2dw1=0 f_{21}(x_1, x_2) \frac{dx_1}{dw_1} + f_{22}(x_1, x_2) \frac{dx_2}{dw_1} = 0 f21​(x1​,x2​)dw1​dx1​​+f22​(x1​,x2​)dw1​dx2​​=0

Simply:

f11∂x1∂w1+f12∂x2∂w1=1 f_{11} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} + f_{12} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} = 1 f11​∂w1​∂x1​​+f12​∂w1​∂x2​​=1
