f21∂x1∂w1+f22∂x2∂w1=0 f_{21} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} + f_{22} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} = 0 f21​∂w1​∂x1​​+f22​∂w1​∂x2​​=0

Thus:

(f11f12f21f22)⋅(∂x1∂w1∂x2∂w1)=(10) \begin{pmatrix} f_{11} & f_{12} \\ f_{21} & f_{22} \end{pmatrix}\cdot\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} \\ \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} \end{pmatrix}=\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix} (f11​f21​​f12​f22​​)⋅(∂w1​∂x1​​∂w1​∂x2​​​)=(10​)

Using Cramer’s rule:

∂x1∂w1=(1f120f22)(f11f12f21f22) \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} = \frac{ \begin{pmatrix} 1 & f_{12} \\ 0 & f_{22} \end{pmatrix} }{ \begin{pmatrix} f_{11} & f_{12} \\ f_{21} & f_{22} \end{pmatrix} } ∂w1​∂x1​​=(f11​f21​​f12​f22​​)(10​f12​f22​​)​

This is the comparative statics of x1x_1x1​ w.r.t. w1w_1w1​, in a two-input framework.

You can also get an expression for ∂x2∂w1\frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1}∂w1​∂x2​​ using Cramer’s rule.

Comparative Static Analysis (C.S.A) with respect to W1W_1W1​:

We are interested in the comparative static analysis (C.S.A.) with respect to W1W_1W1​:

f11∂x1∂W1+f12∂x2∂W1=0 f_{11} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_1} + f_{12} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_1} = 0 f11​∂W1​∂x1​​+f12​∂W1​∂x2​​=0
f21∂x1∂W1+f22∂x2∂W1=1 f_{21} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_1} + f_{22} \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_1} = 1 f21​∂W1​∂x1​​+f22​∂W1​∂x2​​=1

We can also integrate the C.S.A. with respect to W1W_1W1​ and W2W_2W2​ as follows:

(f11f12f21f22)(∂x1∂W1∂x1∂W2∂x2∂W1∂x2∂W2)=(1001) \begin{pmatrix} f_{11} & f_{12} \\ f_{21} & f_{22} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_1} & \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_2} \\ \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_1} & \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_2} \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} 1 &0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} (f11​f21​​f12​f22​​)(∂W1​∂x1​​∂W1​∂x2​​​∂W2​∂x1​​∂W2​∂x2​​​)=(10​01​)

We now proceed to integrate C.S.A. with respect to both W1W_1W1​ and W2W_2W2​. The substitution matrix SSS describes how the firm substitutes one input for another as factor prices change:

S=(∂x1∂W1∂x1∂W2∂x2∂W1∂x2∂W2) S = \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_1} & \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_2} \\ \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_1} & \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_2} \end{pmatrix} S=(∂W1​∂x1​​∂W1​∂x2​​​∂W2​∂x1​​∂W2​∂x2​​​)

The substitution matrix is the inverse of the Hessian matrix HHH:

H=(f11f12f21f22) H = \begin{pmatrix} f_{11} & f_{12} \\ f_{21} & f_{22} \end{pmatrix} H=(f11​f21​​f12​f22​​)

Important Implications:

  • The Hessian matrix is a symmetric negative definite matrix by Young’s theorem. Therefore, the substitution matrix must also be symmetric and negative definite.

Hence:

  1. ∂x1∂W1\frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_1}∂W1​∂x1​​ and ∂x2∂W2\frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_2}∂W2​∂x2​​ are negative (from the diagonal elements).
  2. ∂x1∂W2=∂x2∂W1\frac{\partial x_1}{\partial W_2} = \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial W_1}∂W2​∂x1​​=∂W1​∂x2​​ (from symmetry).

Generalizing to nnn inputs and p=1p = 1p=1:

Df(x(W))=W D f(x(W)) = W Df(x(W))=W
Differentiating with respect to WWW:

D2f(x(W))⋅Dx(W)=I D^2 f(x(W)) \cdot D x(W) = I D2f(x(W))⋅Dx(W)=I

Thus:

Dx(W)=[D2f(x(W))]−1 D x(W) = \left[ D^2 f(x(W)) \right]^{-1} Dx(W)=[D2f(x(W))]−1

Comparative Statics using Algebra - Weak Axiom of Profit Maximization (WAPM)

Suppose we have some empirical data:

  1. Data on observed price vectors ptp_tpt​, for t=1,2,…,Tt = 1, 2, \dots, Tt=1,2,…,T
  2. Data on associated net output vectors y(pt)y(p_t)y(pt​) for t=1,2,…,Tt = 1, 2, \dots, Tt=1,2,…,T

In the net supply format, this can be written as:

(pt,y(pt))fort=1,2,…,T (p_t, y(p_t)) \quad \text{for} \quad t = 1, 2, \dots, T (pt​,y(pt​))fort=1,2,…,T

The first question is: What does profit maximization imply about this data?

If the firm is maximizing profits, the observed net output choice at price ptp_tpt​ must have a profit level at least as great as the profit from any other net output the firm could have chosen.
Well, we do not have information on all other feasible choices in this situation, but we know some of them ysy_sys​ for s=1...Ts = 1...Ts=1...T (choices chosen in other situations)

A necessary condition for profit maximization is:

pt⋅yt≥pt⋅ysfor alltands=1,2,…,T p_t \cdot y_t \geq p_t \cdot y_s \quad \text{for all} \quad t \quad \text{and} \quad s = 1, 2, \dots, T pt​⋅yt​≥pt​⋅ys​for alltands=1,2,…,T

This is known as the Weak Axiom of Profit Maximization (WAPM).

Let us depict this graphically:

Revisiting the Isoprofit Line in Profit Maximization
We will represent this graphically, showing both output and input decisions.

Left Figure:

The firm selects y2y_2y2​ as the output at price P2P_2P2​. However, if P2y2>P1y1P_2 y_2 > P_1 y_1P2​y2​>P1​y1​, this violates the Weak Axiom of Profit Maximization (WAPM).

Right Figure:

Here, the firm selects y2y_2y2​ at price P2P_2P2​, and P2y2<P1y1P_2 y_2 < P_1 y_1P2​y2​<P1​y1​ satisfies WAPM.

Hint: Isoprofit lines are associated with specific price levels. \text{Hint: Isoprofit lines are associated with specific price levels.} Hint: Isoprofit lines are associated with specific price levels.

Using y=(Π+w)pxy = \frac{(\Pi + w)}{p} xy=p(Π+w)​x, we can examine the slope and intercept of these isoprofit lines. WAPM is a simple but very useful condition in profit maximization.

Consequences of WAPM

Suppose we take two observations, ttt and sss:

  1. ptyt≥ptys  ⟹  pt(yt−ys)≥0p_t y_t \geq p_t y_s \implies p_t (y_t - y_s) \geq 0pt​yt​≥pt​ys​⟹pt​(yt​−ys​)≥0
  2. Similarly, −ps(yt−ys)≥0-p_s (y_t - y_s) \geq 0−ps​(yt​−ys​)≥0

Adding these two inequalities, we get:

(pt−ps)⋅(yt−ys)≥0 (p_t - p_s) \cdot (y_t - y_s) \geq 0 (pt​−ps​)⋅(yt​−ys​)≥0

This means the inner product of the vector of price changes with the associated vector of changes in net outputs must be non-negative:

Δp⋅Δy≥0 \Delta p \cdot \Delta y \geq 0 Δp⋅Δy≥0

For example, suppose Δp=(1,0,…,0)\Delta p = (1, 0, \dots, 0)Δp=(1,0,…,0), which indicates that the price of the first good has increased. This implies that Δy1≥0\Delta y_1 \geq 0Δy1​≥0:

  • If the first good is an output good, Δy1≥0\Delta y_1 \geq 0Δy1​≥0, meaning the firm increases supply of the good due to a rise in its own price.
  • If the first good is an input good, Δy1≤0\Delta y_1 \leq 0Δy1​≤0, meaning the demand for the factor decreases as its price rises.

This graphical and algebraic depiction explains the consequences of WAPM and how price and output adjustments are linked.

Chapter 3 - Profit function (Microeconomics)

Objective:

Given any production set YYY, we want to:

  1. Calculate the maximum profit—obtain an expression.
  2. Determine the factor demand functions x(p)x(p)x(p).
  3. Derive the firm’s supply functions y(p)=f(x(p))y(p) = f(x(p))y(p)=f(x(p)).
  4. Obtain the profit function π(p)=p⋅y(p)−w⋅x(p)\pi(p) = p \cdot y(p) - w \cdot x(p)π(p)=p⋅y(p)−w⋅x(p).

This profit function provides the maximum attainable profit at prices ppp. The profit function has several important properties that we will explore.

Mathematical Perspective:

From a mathematical standpoint, the objective function in this problem is a linear function of prices:

π(p)=max⁡y∈Yp⋅y\pi(p) = \max_{y \in Y} p \cdot yπ(p)=maxy∈Y​p⋅y

Properties of the Profit Function

These properties are derived solely from the assumption of profit maximization, without requiring assumptions about convexity, monotonicity, or other regularity conditions.

  1. Non-decreasing in output prices, non-increasing in input prices:

    If pi′≥pip_i' \ge p_ipi′​≥pi​ for all outputs and pj′≤pjp_j' \le p_jpj′​≤pj​ for all inputs, then π(p′)≥π(p)\pi(p') \ge \pi(p)π(p′)≥π(p).

    Proof:

    • Let yyy be the profit-maximizing plan at ppp and y′y'y′ be the profit-maximizing plan at p′p'p′.
    • Then, π(p)=p⋅y\pi(p) = p \cdot yπ(p)=p⋅y and π(p′)=p′⋅y′\pi(p') = p' \cdot y'π(p′)=p′⋅y′.
    • By the Weak Axiom of Profit Maximization (WAPM), since p⋅y≥p⋅y′p \cdot y \ge p \cdot y'p⋅y≥p⋅y′ and p′⋅y′≥p′⋅yp' \cdot y' \ge p' \cdot yp′⋅y′≥p′⋅y, and since pi′≥pip_i' \ge p_ipi′​≥pi​ and pj′≤pjp_j' \le p_jpj′​≤pj​, we have p′⋅y′≥p⋅yp' \cdot y' \ge p \cdot yp′⋅y′≥p⋅y.
    • Combining, we get π(p′)≥π(p)\pi(p') \ge \pi(p)π(p′)≥π(p).

  2. Homogeneous of degree 1 in ppp:

    π(tp)=tπ(p)\pi(tp) = t\pi(p)π(tp)=tπ(p) for all t≥0t \ge 0t≥0.

    Proof:

    • Let yyy be a maximizing net output vector at ppp.
    • Then, π(p)=p⋅y≥p⋅y′\pi(p) = p \cdot y \ge p \cdot y'π(p)=p⋅y≥p⋅y′ for all y′∈Yy' \in Yy′∈Y.
    • Multiplying both sides by ttt, we get t⋅p⋅y≥t⋅p⋅y′t \cdot p \cdot y \ge t \cdot p \cdot y't⋅p⋅y≥t⋅p⋅y′.
    • This implies (tp)⋅y≥(tp)⋅y′(tp) \cdot y \ge (tp) \cdot y'(tp)⋅y≥(tp)⋅y′.
    • Thus, π(tp)=t⋅p⋅y=t⋅π(p)\pi(tp) = t \cdot p \cdot y = t \cdot \pi(p)π(tp)=t⋅p⋅y=t⋅π(p).

  3. Convex in ppp:

    Let p′′=tp+(1−t)p′p'' = tp + (1-t)p'p′′=tp+(1−t)p′ for 0≤t≤10 \le t \le 10≤t≤1. Then, π(p′′)≤tπ(p)+(1−t)π(p′)\pi(p'') \le t\pi(p) + (1-t)\pi(p')π(p′′)≤tπ(p)+(1−t)π(p′).

    Proof:

    • Let yyy maximize profits at ppp, y′y'y′ maximize profits at p′p'p′, and y′′y''y′′ maximize profits at p′′p''p′′.
    • Then, π(p′′)=p′′⋅y′′=(tp+(1−t)p′)⋅y′′=t⋅p⋅y′′+(1−t)p′⋅y′′\pi(p'') = p'' \cdot y'' = (tp + (1-t)p') \cdot y'' = t \cdot p \cdot y'' + (1-t)p' \cdot y''π(p′′)=p′′⋅y′′=(tp+(1−t)p′)⋅y′′=t⋅p⋅y′′+(1−t)p′⋅y′′.
    • Now, π(p)=p⋅y≥p⋅y′′\pi(p) = p \cdot y \ge p \cdot y''π(p)=p⋅y≥p⋅y′′, which implies t⋅p⋅y≥t⋅p⋅y′′t \cdot p \cdot y \ge t \cdot p \cdot y''t⋅p⋅y≥t⋅p⋅y′′.
    • Similarly, π(p′)=p′⋅y′≥p′⋅y′′\pi(p') = p' \cdot y' \ge p' \cdot y''π(p′)=p′⋅y′≥p′⋅y′′, which implies (1−t)⋅p′⋅y′≥(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′′(1-t) \cdot p' \cdot y' \ge (1-t) \cdot p' \cdot y''(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′≥(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′′.
    • Adding these inequalities, we get t⋅p⋅y+(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′≥t⋅p⋅y′′+(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′′t \cdot p \cdot y + (1-t) \cdot p' \cdot y' \ge t \cdot p \cdot y'' + (1-t) \cdot p' \cdot y''t⋅p⋅y+(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′≥t⋅p⋅y′′+(1−t)⋅p′⋅y′′.
    • This implies tπ(p)+(1−t)π(p′)≥π(p′′)t\pi(p) + (1-t)\pi(p') \ge \pi(p'')tπ(p)+(1−t)π(p′)≥π(p′′).

  4. Continuous in ppp: This ensures that π(p)\pi(p)π(p) is well-defined.

Intuitive Understanding of the Properties:

  1. Homogeneous of degree 1 in prices: This intuitively means that if all prices are scaled by a factor, the profit also scales by the same factor. For example, if the prices of both outputs and inputs double, the profit will also double. This makes sense because the firm’s production possibilities and optimal choices remain the same in real terms.
  2. Increasing in output prices: This is intuitive as higher output prices lead to higher revenue for the same quantity of output, thus increasing profits.
  3. Convexity in prices: Convexity implies that the firm can take advantage of price fluctuations. The firm can adjust its production plan in response to price changes, leading to higher profits compared to a situation where it sticks to a fixed plan. For instance, if the price of an output increases, the firm can increase its production of that output to take advantage of the higher price. Conversely, if the price of an input increases, the firm can reduce its use of that input or substitute it with a cheaper alternative.

Economic Rationale for Convexity Property

Consider the graph of profits versus the price of the output good.

At the price vector (P∗,w∗)(P^*,w^*)(P∗,w∗), suppose the profit-maximizing plan is (y∗,x∗)(y^*,x^*)(y∗,x∗). This leads to a profit of π=p∗y∗−w∗x∗\pi=p^*y^*-w^*x^*π=p∗y∗−w∗x∗, where y∗y^*y∗, x∗x^*x∗, and w∗w^*w∗ are unchanged.

Suppose ppp increases, but the firm does not change (y∗,x∗)(y^*,x^*)(y∗,x∗).

So, the firm’s profit behaves as expressed by a straight line. We call this the passive profit line because the firm does not respond to the price increase by changing its optimal x∗x^*x∗ or y∗y^*y∗.

Now, the profits from pursuing the optimal policy must yield profits as large as the passive profit line. So for every point, except the first point of (P∗,w∗)(P^*,w^*)(P∗,w∗), the profit line must be higher than the passive profit line. Hence π(p)\pi(p)π(p) is a convex function.

Practical Implication:

These properties are crucial when analyzing accounting data. For instance, if profits don’t scale proportionally when all prices are scaled up, it indicates that the firm is not maximizing profits. This could be due to various reasons such as inefficiencies in production, incorrect price expectations, or managerial constraints.

Example:

Consider a competitive industry facing a randomly fluctuating output price:

  • p1p_1p1​ with probability qqq
  • p2p_2p2​ with probability (1−q)(1-q)(1−q)

How does this affect a typical firm’s profits?

Since the profit function is convex, we have:

π(pˉ)≤qπ(p1)+(1−q)π(p2)\pi(\bar{p}) \le q\pi(p_1) + (1-q)\pi(p_2)π(pˉ​)≤qπ(p1​)+(1−q)π(p2​)

where pˉ=p1q+p2(1−q)\bar{p} = p_1q + p_2(1-q)pˉ​=p1​q+p2​(1−q).

This implies that a fluctuating price leads to at least as much profit as a fixed average price. The firm benefits from adjusting its production according to the prevailing price level—expanding when the price is high and vice versa. This flexibility allows the firm to take advantage of favorable price movements and mitigate the impact of unfavorable ones.

Supply and Demand Functions from the Profit Function

The profit function contains all the economically relevant information about the firm’s behavior. We can use the profit function to derive the firm’s net supply functions.

Suppose we have the firm’s supply function y(p)y(p)y(p). And we want the profit function - what do we do? This is easy. We substitute this into our profit expression and get π(p)=p⋅y(p)\pi(p) = p \cdot y(p)π(p)=p⋅y(p).

Now, suppose we have the profit function and are asked to find the firm’s supply function - How?

We use the Hotelling’s Lemma:

Let yi(p)y_i(p)yi​(p) be the firm’s net supply function of good iii. Then:

yi(p)=∂π(p)∂piy_i(p) = \frac{\partial \pi(p)}{\partial p_i}yi​(p)=∂pi​∂π(p)​ for i=1,...,ni = 1, ..., ni=1,...,n

assuming that this derivative exists and pi>0p_i > 0pi​>0.

Proof:

Suppose y∗y^*y∗ is a profit-maximizing net output vector at prices p∗p^*p∗. Then we define a function:

g(p)=π(p)−p⋅y∗g(p) = \pi(p) - p \cdot y^*g(p)=π(p)−p⋅y∗

Here π(p)=p⋅y\pi(p) = p \cdot yπ(p)=p⋅y is the profit function. Thus, the profit-maximizing plan at price ppp will be at least as good as y∗y^*y∗, since y∗y^*y∗ is feasible but not necessarily optimal at prices ppp.

This implies that g(p)≥0g(p) \ge 0g(p)≥0 for all ppp and g(p∗)=0g(p^*) = 0g(p∗)=0. Therefore, g(p)g(p)g(p) attains a minimum at p=p∗p = p^*p=p∗.

Assuming that π(p)\pi(p)π(p) is differentiable, the first-order condition for a minimum is:

∇g(p∗)=0\nabla g(p^*) = 0∇g(p∗)=0

This gives us:

∂π(p∗)∂pi−yi∗=0\frac{\partial \pi(p^*)}{\partial p_i} - y_i^* = 0∂pi​∂π(p∗)​−yi∗​=0

or

yi∗=∂π(p∗)∂piy_i^* = \frac{\partial \pi(p^*)}{\partial p_i}yi∗​=∂pi​∂π(p∗)​

Since this holds for any price vector p∗p^*p∗, we have:

yi(p)=∂π(p)∂piy_i(p) = \frac{\partial \pi(p)}{\partial p_i}yi​(p)=∂pi​∂π(p)​

This completes the proof.

Intuitive Explanation:

Hotelling’s Lemma states that the firm’s net supply function for a good is equal to the partial derivative of the profit function with respect to the price of that good. Intuitively, this means that a small increase in the price of a good will lead to an increase in the firm’s supply of that good, proportional to the derivative of the profit function.

Implications:

Hotelling’s Lemma is a powerful tool for analyzing firm behavior. It allows us to:

  • Derive the firm’s supply function directly from its profit function.
  • Analyze how changes in prices affect the firm’s supply decisions.
  • Understand the relationship between the firm’s profit-maximizing behavior and its supply function.

Note:

The assumption of differentiability of the profit function is crucial for Hotelling’s Lemma to hold. If the profit function is not differentiable, the supply function may not be well-defined.

Let us consider a single output and a single input case.

The profit function of a firm can be expressed as:

Π(x)=P⋅f(x)−w⋅x\Pi(x) = P \cdot f(x) - w \cdot xΠ(x)=P⋅f(x)−w⋅x

where:

  • PPP is the price of the output.
  • f(x)f(x)f(x) is the production function, representing the output produced using input xxx.
  • www is the price of the input.

The first-order condition (F.O.C) for profit maximization is:

P⋅df(x)dx−w=0P \cdot \frac{df(x)}{dx} - w = 0P⋅dxdf(x)​−w=0

This condition gives us the demand function for the input, x(P,w)x(P,w)x(P,w), which represents the optimal amount of input demanded by the firm at given prices PPP and www.

Substituting the demand function back into the profit function, we get:

Π(P,w)=P⋅f(x(P,w))−w⋅x(P,w)\Pi(P,w) = P \cdot f(x(P,w)) - w \cdot x(P,w)Π(P,w)=P⋅f(x(P,w))−w⋅x(P,w)

This is the profit function expressed in terms of the prices of output and input.

Differentiating the profit function with respect to www, we get:

∂π∂w=P⋅∂f(x(P,w))∂x⋅∂x∂w−w⋅∂x∂w−x(P,w)\frac{\partial \pi}{\partial w} = P \cdot \frac{\partial f(x(P,w))}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{\partial x}{\partial w} - w \cdot \frac{\partial x}{\partial w} - x(P,w)∂w∂π​=P⋅∂x∂f(x(P,w))​⋅∂w∂x​−w⋅∂w∂x​−x(P,w)

Rearranging and using the F.O.C, we get:

∂π∂w=[P⋅∂f(x(P,w))∂x−w]⋅∂x∂w−x(P,w)=−x(P,w)\frac{\partial \pi}{\partial w} = [P \cdot \frac{\partial f(x(P,w))}{\partial x} - w] \cdot \frac{\partial x}{\partial w} - x(P,w) = -x(P,w)∂w∂π​=[P⋅∂x∂f(x(P,w))​−w]⋅∂w∂x​−x(P,w)=−x(P,w)

This result demonstrates the economic rationale behind Hotelling’s lemma, which states that the derivative of the profit function with respect to the input price is equal to the negative of the input demand function.

Economic Rationale:

When the price of an output increases, there are two effects:

  1. Direct effect: The price increase leads to higher profits even at the same level of output. This is because the revenue increases while the cost remains the same.
  2. Indirect effect: The increase in price induces the firm to change its level of output by a small amount. This is because the firm wants to take advantage of the higher price by producing more output. However, since the input is already at its profit-maximizing level, the indirect effect will be zero.

This is an application of the Envelope Theorem, which states that the derivative of the maximized value of a function with respect to a parameter is equal to the derivative of the objective function with respect to the parameter, holding the choice variables constant at their optimal values.

The Envelope Theorem

Consider a maximization problem with parameter aaa:

M(a)=max⁡xf(x,a)M(a) = \max_x f(x,a)M(a)=maxx​f(x,a)

M(a)M(a)M(a) is the maximized value of the function, which is a function of the parameter aaa.

Let x(a)x(a)x(a) be the value of xxx that solves the problem. Then:

M(a)=f(x(a),a)M(a) = f(x(a),a)M(a)=f(x(a),a)

This simply says that the optimized value of the function is equal to the function evaluated at the optimal choice of xxx.

Differentiating both sides with respect to aaa, we get:

dM(a)da=∂f(x(a),a)∂x⋅dx(a)da+∂f(x(a),a)∂a\frac{dM(a)}{da} = \frac{\partial f(x(a),a)}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{dx(a)}{da} + \frac{\partial f(x(a),a)}{\partial a}dadM(a)​=∂x∂f(x(a),a)​⋅dadx(a)​+∂a∂f(x(a),a)​

The first term on the right-hand side represents the indirect effect of aaa on M(a)M(a)M(a) through the change in the optimal choice of xxx. The second term represents the direct effect of aaa on M(a)M(a)M(a), holding xxx constant at its optimal value.

The Envelope Theorem states that the indirect effect is zero, i.e.,

∂f(x(a),a)∂x⋅dx(a)da=0\frac{\partial f(x(a),a)}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{dx(a)}{da} = 0∂x∂f(x(a),a)​⋅dadx(a)​=0

This is because at the optimal choice of xxx, the derivative of the objective function with respect to xxx is zero.

Therefore, we have:

dM(a)da=∂f(x(a),a)∂a\frac{dM(a)}{da} = \frac{\partial f(x(a),a)}{\partial a}dadM(a)​=∂a∂f(x(a),a)​

This means that the derivative of the maximized value of the function with respect to a parameter is equal to the derivative of the objective function with respect to the parameter, holding the choice variables constant at their optimal values.

Applying Hotelling’s Lemma to a Simple One-Input, One-Output Profit Maximization

Consider a firm that uses a single input, xxx, to produce a single output, yyy. The firm’s production function is y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x), and the prices of the output and input are ppp and www, respectively.

The firm’s profit function is:

π(p,w)=max⁡x[p⋅f(x)−w⋅x]\pi(p,w) = \max_x [p \cdot f(x) - w \cdot x]π(p,w)=maxx​[p⋅f(x)−w⋅x]

The first-order condition for profit maximization is:

p⋅f′(x)−w=0p \cdot f'(x) - w = 0p⋅f′(x)−w=0

This condition implicitly defines the firm’s demand function for the input, x(p,w)x(p,w)x(p,w).

Applying Hotelling’s Lemma, we can find the firm’s supply function for the output:

y(p,w)=∂π(p,w)∂p=f(x(p,w))y(p,w) = \frac{\partial \pi(p,w)}{\partial p} = f(x(p,w))y(p,w)=∂p∂π(p,w)​=f(x(p,w))

This result is intuitive: the firm’s supply of output is simply the output produced using the optimal amount of input.

Similarly, we can find the firm’s demand function for the input:

x(p,w)=−∂π(p,w)∂w=x(p,w)x(p,w) = -\frac{\partial \pi(p,w)}{\partial w} = x(p,w)x(p,w)=−∂w∂π(p,w)​=x(p,w)

This result confirms that the demand function derived from Hotelling’s Lemma is consistent with the demand function obtained from the first-order condition.

Comparative Statics

We can use Hotelling’s Lemma to analyze the comparative statics of the firm’s supply and demand functions. For example, we can examine how the firm’s supply of output changes in response to a change in the output price:

∂y(p,w)∂p=f′(x(p,w))⋅∂x(p,w)∂p\frac{\partial y(p,w)}{\partial p} = f'(x(p,w)) \cdot \frac{\partial x(p,w)}{\partial p}∂p∂y(p,w)​=f′(x(p,w))⋅∂p∂x(p,w)​

The first term on the right-hand side, f′(x(p,w))f'(x(p,w))f′(x(p,w)), is the marginal product of the input. The second term, ∂x(p,w)∂p\frac{\partial x(p,w)}{\partial p}∂p∂x(p,w)​, is the derivative of the input demand function with respect to the output price.

Since the marginal product of the input is positive, the sign of ∂y(p,w)∂p\frac{\partial y(p,w)}{\partial p}∂p∂y(p,w)​ depends on the sign of ∂x(p,w)∂p\frac{\partial x(p,w)}{\partial p}∂p∂x(p,w)​. If the input is a normal good, then ∂x(p,w)∂p>0\frac{\partial x(p,w)}{\partial p} > 0∂p∂x(p,w)​>0, and the firm’s supply of output increases in response to an increase in the output price.

Similarly, we can analyze how the firm’s demand for the input changes in response to a change in the input price:

∂x(p,w)∂w=−∂2π(p,w)∂w2\frac{\partial x(p,w)}{\partial w} = -\frac{\partial^2 \pi(p,w)}{\partial w^2}∂w∂x(p,w)​=−∂w2∂2π(p,w)​

The right-hand side is the second derivative of the profit function with respect to the input price. If the profit function is concave in the input price, then ∂2π(p,w)∂w2<0\frac{\partial^2 \pi(p,w)}{\partial w^2} < 0∂w2∂2π(p,w)​<0, and the firm’s demand for the input decreases in response to an increase in the input price.

Profit function is homogenous of degree 1 in prices.

π(tp,tw)=max⁡x[tp⋅f(x)−tw⋅x]\pi(tp,tw) = \max_x [tp \cdot f(x) - tw \cdot x]π(tp,tw)=maxx​[tp⋅f(x)−tw⋅x]

=t⋅max⁡x[p⋅f(x)−w⋅x]= t \cdot \max_x [p \cdot f(x) - w \cdot x]=t⋅maxx​[p⋅f(x)−w⋅x]

=t⋅π(p,w)= t \cdot \pi(p,w)=t⋅π(p,w)

This shows that if we multiply both the output price and the input price by a constant factor ttt, the profit also gets multiplied by the same factor ttt. This makes intuitive sense: if all prices are scaled up by the same factor, the firm’s production decisions and profits will also scale up proportionally.

Now, differentiate both sides of the above equation with respect to ttt.

∂π(tp,tw)∂(tp)⋅p+∂π(tp,tw)∂(tw)⋅w=π(p,w)\frac{\partial \pi(tp,tw)}{\partial (tp)} \cdot p + \frac{\partial \pi(tp,tw)}{\partial (tw)} \cdot w = \pi(p,w)∂(tp)∂π(tp,tw)​⋅p+∂(tw)∂π(tp,tw)​⋅w=π(p,w)

Set t=1t = 1t=1 to get:

∂π(p,w)∂p⋅p+∂π(p,w)∂w⋅w=π(p,w)\frac{\partial \pi(p,w)}{\partial p} \cdot p + \frac{\partial \pi(p,w)}{\partial w} \cdot w = \pi(p,w)∂p∂π(p,w)​⋅p+∂w∂π(p,w)​⋅w=π(p,w)

Using Hotelling’s Lemma, we can substitute the partial derivatives with the supply and demand functions:

y(p,w)⋅p+(−x(p,w))⋅w=π(p,w)y(p,w) \cdot p + (-x(p,w)) \cdot w = \pi(p,w)y(p,w)⋅p+(−x(p,w))⋅w=π(p,w)

This gives us the following identity:

p⋅y(p,w)−w⋅x(p,w)=π(p,w)p \cdot y(p,w) - w \cdot x(p,w) = \pi(p,w)p⋅y(p,w)−w⋅x(p,w)=π(p,w)

This identity simply states that the profit is equal to the revenue minus the cost.

scaling up all prices by some factor ttt won’t change the optimal choice of the firm!

Profit function is a convex function of ppp.

So, the Hessian matrix must be positive semi-definite matrix.

In a KKK good case,

(∂2π∂p12∂2π∂p1∂p2∂2π∂p2∂p1∂2π∂p22)=(∂y1∂p1∂y1∂p2∂y2∂p1∂y2∂p2)\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_1^2} & \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_1 \partial p_2} \\ \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_2 \partial p_1} & \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_2^2} \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial y_1}{\partial p_1} & \frac{\partial y_1}{\partial p_2} \\ \frac{\partial y_2}{\partial p_1} & \frac{\partial y_2}{\partial p_2} \end{pmatrix}(∂p12​∂2π​∂p2​∂p1​∂2π​​∂p1​∂p2​∂2π​∂p22​∂2π​​)=(∂p1​∂y1​​∂p1​∂y2​​​∂p2​∂y1​​∂p2​∂y2​​​)

How the net supply of good iii changes as the price of good jjj changes. ←\leftarrow← substitution matrix.

Since the left side is a symmetric & positive semi-definite matrix:

∂yi∂pi>0\frac{\partial y_i}{\partial p_i} > 0∂pi​∂yi​​>0 and ∂yj∂pi=∂yi∂pj\frac{\partial y_j}{\partial p_i} = \frac{\partial y_i}{\partial p_j}∂pi​∂yj​​=∂pj​∂yi​​.

Le Chatelier’s Principle

Short-run versus long-run response of a firm’s supply behavior:

The long-run response of a firm’s supply to a change in price is at least as large as the short-run response, since it has more factors to adjust in the long run.

Proof:

Simple case of one output. Input prices are assumed to be fixed, so π\piπ depends only on the price of the output.

Let πs(p,z)\pi_s(p,z)πs​(p,z) be the short-run profit function, where zzz is a fixed input in the short run. Let the long-run maximizing demand for zzz be given by z(p)z(p)z(p).

So, πL(p)=πs(p,z(p))\pi_L(p) = \pi_s(p,z(p))πL​(p)=πs​(p,z(p))

Let p∗p^*p∗ be some output price and z∗=z(p∗)z^* = z(p^*)z∗=z(p∗) be the optimal long-run demand for zzz at p∗p^*p∗.

Now, long-run profits will always be as large as short-run profits. Why? Because even the restricted factor can be adjusted in the long run.

So, h(p)=πL(p)−πs(p,z∗)=πs(p,z(p))−πs(p,z∗)≥0h(p) = \pi_L(p) - \pi_s(p,z^*) = \pi_s(p,z(p)) - \pi_s(p,z^*) \ge 0h(p)=πL​(p)−πs​(p,z∗)=πs​(p,z(p))−πs​(p,z∗)≥0 for all prices ppp.

At p∗p^*p∗, h(p∗)=0h(p^*) = 0h(p∗)=0 and h(p)≥0h(p) \ge 0h(p)≥0 for all ppp. So, the function h(p)h(p)h(p) reaches a minimum at p∗p^*p∗.

Therefore, the first-order condition (F.O.C) is:

dh(p∗)dp=0\frac{dh(p^*)}{dp} = 0dpdh(p∗)​=0

And the second-order condition (S.O.C) is:

d2h(p∗)dp2≥0\frac{d^2h(p^*)}{dp^2} \ge 0dp2d2h(p∗)​≥0

This implies:

∂2πL(p∗)∂p2−∂2πs(p∗,z∗)∂p2≥0\frac{\partial^2 \pi_L(p^*)}{\partial p^2} - \frac{\partial^2 \pi_s(p^*,z^*)}{\partial p^2} \ge 0∂p2∂2πL​(p∗)​−∂p2∂2πs​(p∗,z∗)​≥0

⇒∂yL∂p(p∗)−∂ys∂p(p∗,z∗)≥0\Rightarrow \frac{\partial y_L}{\partial p}(p^*) - \frac{\partial y_s}{\partial p}(p^*,z^*) \ge 0⇒∂p∂yL​​(p∗)−∂p∂ys​​(p∗,z∗)≥0

Hence, the long-run supply response to a change in price is at least as large as the short-run supply response at z∗=z(p∗)z^* = z(p^*)z∗=z(p∗).

Profit function is homogenous of degree 1 in prices.

π(tp,tw)=max⁡x[tp⋅f(x)−tw⋅x]\pi(tp,tw) = \max_x [tp \cdot f(x) - tw \cdot x]π(tp,tw)=maxx​[tp⋅f(x)−tw⋅x]

=t⋅max⁡x[p⋅f(x)−w⋅x]= t \cdot \max_x [p \cdot f(x) - w \cdot x]=t⋅maxx​[p⋅f(x)−w⋅x]

=t⋅π(p,w)= t \cdot \pi(p,w)=t⋅π(p,w)

So, ∂π(tp)∂(tp)=∂π(p)∂p\frac{\partial \pi(tp)}{\partial (tp)} = \frac{\partial \pi(p)}{\partial p}∂(tp)∂π(tp)​=∂p∂π(p)​

In a KKK good case,

(∂2π∂p12∂2π∂p1∂p2∂2π∂p2∂p1∂2π∂p22)=(∂y1∂p1∂y1∂p2∂y2∂p1∂y2∂p2)\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_1^2} & \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_1 \partial p_2} \\ \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_2 \partial p_1} & \frac{\partial^2 \pi}{\partial p_2^2} \end{pmatrix}= \begin{pmatrix} \frac{\partial y_1}{\partial p_1} & \frac{\partial y_1}{\partial p_2} \\ \frac{\partial y_2}{\partial p_1} & \frac{\partial y_2}{\partial p_2} \end{pmatrix}(∂p12​∂2π​∂p2​∂p1​∂2π​​∂p1​∂p2​∂2π​∂p22​∂2π​​)=(∂p1​∂y1​​∂p1​∂y2​​​∂p2​∂y1​​∂p2​∂y2​​​)
↓\downarrow↓

Since the left side is a symmetric & positive semi-definite matrix:

∂yi∂pi>0\frac{\partial y_i}{\partial p_i} > 0∂pi​∂yi​​>0 and ∂yj∂pi=∂yi∂pj\frac{\partial y_j}{\partial p_i} = \frac{\partial y_i}{\partial p_j}∂pi​∂yj​​=∂pj​∂yi​​.

Le Chatelier’s Principle

Short-run versus long-run response of a firm’s supply behavior:

The long-run response of a firm’s supply to a change in price is at least as large as the short-run response, since it has more factors to adjust in the long run.

Proof:

Simple case of one output. Input prices are assumed to be fixed, so π\piπ depends only on the price of the output.

Let πs(p,z)\pi_s(p,z)πs​(p,z) be the short-run profit function, where zzz is a fixed input in the short run. Let the long-run maximizing demand for zzz be given by z(p)z(p)z(p).

So, πL(p)=πs(p,z(p))\pi_L(p) = \pi_s(p,z(p))πL​(p)=πs​(p,z(p))

Let p∗p^*p∗ be some output price and z∗=z(p∗)z^* = z(p^*)z∗=z(p∗) be the optimal long-run demand for zzz at p∗p^*p∗.

Now, long-run profits will always be as large as short-run profits. Why? Because even the restricted factor can be adjusted in the long run.

So, h(p)=πL(p)−πs(p,z∗)=πs(p,z(p))−πs(p,z∗)≥0h(p) = \pi_L(p) - \pi_s(p,z^*) = \pi_s(p,z(p)) - \pi_s(p,z^*) \ge 0h(p)=πL​(p)−πs​(p,z∗)=πs​(p,z(p))−πs​(p,z∗)≥0 for all prices ppp.

At p∗p^*p∗, h(p∗)=0h(p^*) = 0h(p∗)=0 and h(p)≥0h(p) \ge 0h(p)≥0 for all ppp. So, the function h(p)h(p)h(p) reaches a minimum at p∗p^*p∗.

Therefore, the first-order condition (F.O.C) is:

dh(p∗)dp=0\frac{dh(p^*)}{dp} = 0dpdh(p∗)​=0

And the second-order condition (S.O.C) is:

d2h(p∗)dp2≥0\frac{d^2h(p^*)}{dp^2} \ge 0dp2d2h(p∗)​≥0

This implies:

∂2πL(p∗)∂p2−∂2πs(p∗,z∗)∂p2≥0\frac{\partial^2 \pi_L(p^*)}{\partial p^2} - \frac{\partial^2 \pi_s(p^*,z^*)}{\partial p^2} \ge 0∂p2∂2πL​(p∗)​−∂p2∂2πs​(p∗,z∗)​≥0

⇒∂yL∂p(p∗)−∂ys∂p(p∗,z∗)≥0\Rightarrow \frac{\partial y_L}{\partial p}(p^*) - \frac{\partial y_s}{\partial p}(p^*,z^*) \ge 0⇒∂p∂yL​​(p∗)−∂p∂ys​​(p∗,z∗)≥0

Hence, the long-run supply response to a change in price is at least as large as the short-run supply response at z∗=z(p∗)z^* = z(p^*)z∗=z(p∗).

Chapter 4: Cost Minimization

Introduction

In this chapter, we examine the behavior of a cost-minimizing firm.

Why are we interested in cost minimization?

  • Supply behavior: It provides another way to understand the supply behavior of a firm facing competitive output markets.
  • Non-competitive markets: It allows us to model the production behavior of a firm that does not face competitive output markets.

Cost Minimization Problem

We will formalize the problem of minimizing cost while producing a given level of output:

min⁡c=w⋅xsubject tof(x)=y \min c = w \cdot x \quad \text{subject to} \quad f(x) = y minc=w⋅xsubject tof(x)=y

Where:

  • ccc: total cost
  • www: vector of input prices
  • xxx: vector of input quantities
  • f(x)f(x)f(x): production function
  • yyy: level of output

Lagrangian Formulation

We analyze this constrained minimization problem using the Lagrangian method. The Lagrangian is:

L(λ,x)=w⋅x+λ[y−f(x)] L(\lambda, x) = w \cdot x + \lambda [y - f(x)] L(λ,x)=w⋅x+λ[y−f(x)]

Where:

  • (λ)( \lambda )(λ): the Lagrange multiplier (shadow price)
  • w⋅xw \cdot xw⋅x: total cost
  • y−f(x)y - f(x)y−f(x): constraint, where yyy is the given output level, and f(x)f(x)f(x) is the production function

We minimize this Lagrangian with respect to the choice variables xxx and the Lagrange multiplier (λ)( \lambda )(λ).

First Order Conditions (F.O.C)

The first-order conditions for minimizing cost are:

wi−λ∂f(x∗)∂xi=0fori=1,2,...,n w_i - \lambda \frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_i} = 0 \quad \text{for} \quad i = 1, 2, ..., n wi​−λ∂xi​∂f(x∗)​=0fori=1,2,...,n

In vector notation:

w=λDf(x∗) w = \lambda Df(x^*) w=λDf(x∗)

Where:

  • Df(x∗)Df(x^*)Df(x∗): vector of marginal products of each input
  • www: vector of input prices

Interpretation of First Order Conditions

For each pair of inputs iii and jjj from i,j∈{1,2,...,n}i, j \in \{1, 2, ..., n\}i,j∈{1,2,...,n}, we interpret the F.O.C as:

wiwj=∂f(x∗)∂xi∂f(x∗)∂xj \frac{w_i}{w_j} = \frac{\frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_i}}{\frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_j}} wj​wi​​=∂xj​∂f(x∗)​∂xi​∂f(x∗)​​

This equation expresses the equality between the economic rate of substitution and the technical rate of substitution.

Technical Rate of Substitution (TRS)

The technical rate of substitution (TRS) refers to the rate at which factor iii can be substituted for factor jjj while maintaining the same level of output:

TRSij=∂f(x∗)/∂xi∂f(x∗)/∂xj TRS_{ij} = \frac{\partial f(x^*) / \partial x_i}{\partial f(x^*) / \partial x_j} TRSij​=∂f(x∗)/∂xj​∂f(x∗)/∂xi​​

Economic Rate of Substitution

The economic rate of substitution (ERS) is the rate at which factor jjj can be substituted for factor iii while keeping total costs constant:

ERSij=wiwj ERS_{ij} = \frac{w_i}{w_j} ERSij​=wj​wi​​

Thus, the first-order condition shows that at the cost-minimizing point, the economic rate of substitution equals the technical rate of substitution:

ERSij=TRSij ERS_{ij} = TRS_{ij} ERSij​=TRSij​

This implies that the firm is minimizing its costs by choosing the optimal combination of inputs such that the marginal rate of technical substitution is aligned with the ratio of input prices.

Cost Minimization: Second Order Conditions (S.O.C)

First Order Condition (F.O.C)

The economic rate of substitution equals the technical rate of substitution.

Second Order Condition (S.O.C)

For the second-order condition to hold, the bordered Hessian must be negative semi-definite.

[0−Df(x)−Df(x)T−λD2f(x)] \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -Df(x) \\ -Df(x)^T & -\lambda D^2f(x) \end{bmatrix} [0−Df(x)T​−Df(x)−λD2f(x)​]

Where D2f(x)D^2f(x)D2f(x) is the Hessian matrix of f(x)f(x)f(x).

Difficulties:

  1. Non-differentiability: What if f(x)f(x)f(x) is not differentiable? (e.g., Leontief technology).
  2. Corner solutions: What if xi∗=0x^*_i = 0xi∗​=0 for some iii? In such cases, we need to use the Kuhn-Tucker Theorem.

Further Explanation of F.O.C

The economic rate of substitution equals the technical rate of substitution.

Suppose:

wiwj=2andTRS=1 \frac{w_i}{w_j} = 2 \quad \text{and} \quad TRS = 1 wj​wi​​=2andTRS=1

Then ERS>TRSERS > TRSERS>TRS. This implies that we should use one less unit of factor iii and one more unit of factor jjj. This change keeps the output level constant but reduces the cost. Here’s why:

  • By using one less unit of factor iii, we save two units of money (as the price of factor iii is higher).
  • By using one more unit of factor jjj, we only face an additional cost of one unit of money.

Thus, we save on costs by adjusting the input mix, meaning we are not yet cost-minimizing.

Graphical Representation of F.O.C

Isocost Line

The isocost line is given by:

C=w1x1+w2x2 C = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 C=w1​x1​+w2​x2​

We can rewrite this as:

x2=Cw2−w1w2x1 x_2 = \frac{C}{w_2} - \frac{w_1}{w_2} x_1 x2​=w2​C​−w2​w1​​x1​

The slope of the isocost line is:

∣w1w2∣ \left| \frac{w_1}{w_2} \right| ∣∣​w2​w1​​∣∣​

Isoquant

For a given level of output yyy, the isoquant is defined as f(x1,x2)=yf(x_1, x_2) = yf(x1​,x2​)=y. The slope of the isoquant is the technical rate of substitution (TRS). Equilibrium occurs at the point of tangency, where:

∣w1w2∣=∣TRS∣ \left| \frac{w_1}{w_2} \right| = |TRS| ∣∣​w2​w1​​∣∣​=∣TRS∣

Second Order Condition (S.O.C) for Cost Minimization

The Lagrangian for cost minimization is:

L=w1x1+w2x2−λ[f(x1,x2)−y] L = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 - \lambda [f(x_1, x_2) - y] L=w1​x1​+w2​x2​−λ[f(x1​,x2​)−y]

The second-order condition involves the Hessian matrix:

D2L(x1∗,x2∗,λ∗)=[∂2L∂x12∂2L∂x1∂x2∂2L∂x1∂λ∂2L∂x2∂x1∂2L∂x22∂2L∂x2∂λ∂2L∂λ∂x1∂2L∂λ∂x2∂2L∂λ2] D^2 L(x_1^*, x_2^*, \lambda^*) = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_1^2} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_1 \partial \lambda} \\ \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_2 \partial x_1} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_2^2} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_2 \partial \lambda} \\ \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial \lambda \partial x_1} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial \lambda \partial x_2} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial \lambda^2} \end{bmatrix} D2L(x1∗​,x2∗​,λ∗)=⎣⎡​∂x12​∂2L​∂x2​∂x1​∂2L​∂λ∂x1​∂2L​​∂x1​∂x2​∂2L​∂x22​∂2L​∂λ∂x2​∂2L​​∂x1​∂λ∂2L​∂x2​∂λ∂2L​∂λ2∂2L​​⎦⎤​

This can be simplified as:

D2L(x1∗,x2∗,λ∗)=[∂2L∂x12∂2L∂x1∂x2−f1∂2L∂x2∂x1∂2L∂x22−f2−f1−f20] D^2 L(x_1^*, x_2^*, \lambda^*) = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_1^2} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2} & -f_1 \\ \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_2 \partial x_1} & \frac{\partial^2 L}{\partial x_2^2} & -f_2 \\ -f_1 & -f_2 & 0 \end{bmatrix} D2L(x1∗​,x2∗​,λ∗)=⎣⎡​∂x12​∂2L​∂x2​∂x1​∂2L​−f1​​∂x1​∂x2​∂2L​∂x22​∂2L​−f2​​−f1​−f2​0​⎦⎤​

If ∂2f∂xi∂xj=fij\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_i \partial x_j} = f_{ij}∂xi​∂xj​∂2f​=fij​, then:

[0−f1−f2−f1−λf11−λf12−f2−λf21−λf22] \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -f_1 & -f_2 \\ -f_1 & -\lambda f_{11} & -\lambda f_{12} \\ -f_2 & -\lambda f_{21} & -\lambda f_{22} \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​0−f1​−f2​​−f1​−λf11​−λf21​​−f2​−λf12​−λf22​​⎦⎤​

This is the bordered Hessian matrix. The S.O.C for cost minimization requires that the determinant of the bordered Hessian be negative.

Difficulties in Cost Minimization

For each choice of www and yyy, there will be some choice of x∗x^*x∗ that minimizes the cost of producing yyy units of output. This x(w,y)x(w, y)x(w,y) is called the conditional factor demand function, as it depends on both the level of output and the input prices.

The cost function represents the minimal cost at the factor prices www and output level yyy:

c(w,y)=w⋅x(w,y) c(w, y) = w \cdot x(w, y) c(w,y)=w⋅x(w,y)

When Do the F.O.C Get Violated?

  1. Non-differentiable technology: If the production function is not differentiable (e.g., Leontief technology).

  2. Boundary solutions (corner solutions): The F.O.C makes sense only for interior solutions, not for boundary solutions. In the case of corner solutions:

λ∂f(x∗)∂xi≤wi,xi≥0 \lambda \frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_i} \leq w_i, \quad x_i \geq 0 λ∂xi​∂f(x∗)​≤wi​,xi​≥0

If xi>0x_i > 0xi​>0, then:

λ∂f(x∗)∂xi=wi \lambda \frac{\partial f(x^*)}{\partial x_i} = w_i λ∂xi​∂f(x∗)​=wi​

  1. Existence and uniqueness: The issues related to the existence and uniqueness of the profit-maximizing bundle do not arise in the context of cost minimization.

Some examples:

Cobb-Douglas Technology: Cost Minimization Problem

We aim to minimize the cost function under a Cobb-Douglas production technology.

Cost function:
c(w,y)=min⁡x1,x2 w1x1+w2x2,c(w,y) = \min_{x_1, x_2} \, w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2,c(w,y)=x1​,x2​min​w1​x1​+w2​x2​,
subject to the production constraint A⋅x1a⋅x2b=yA \cdot x_1^a \cdot x_2^b = yA⋅x1a​⋅x2b​=y.

Step 1: Substituting the production constraint

We can express x2x_2x2​ as a function of x1x_1x1​ using the production constraint:

x2b=yA⋅x1a⇒x2=(yA⋅x1a)1b x_2^b = \frac{y}{A \cdot x_1^a} \quad \Rightarrow \quad x_2 = \left(\frac{y}{A \cdot x_1^a}\right)^{\frac{1}{b}} x2b​=A⋅x1a​y​⇒x2​=(A⋅x1a​y​)b1​

Step 2: Substituting x2x_2x2​ into the cost function

The cost function becomes:

c(w,y)=w1x1+w2⋅(yA⋅x1a)1b c(w, y) = w_1 x_1 + w_2 \cdot \left(\frac{y}{A \cdot x_1^a}\right)^{\frac{1}{b}} c(w,y)=w1​x1​+w2​⋅(A⋅x1a​y​)b1​

Step 3: First-order conditions (F.O.C)

To minimize the cost, take the derivative of the cost function with respect to x1x_1x1​ and set it to zero:

∂c(w,y)∂x1=w1−ab⋅w2⋅A−1b⋅y1b⋅x1−a+bb=0 \frac{\partial c(w, y)}{\partial x_1} = w_1 - \frac{a}{b} \cdot w_2 \cdot A^{-\frac{1}{b}} \cdot y^{\frac{1}{b}} \cdot x_1^{-\frac{a+b}{b}} = 0 ∂x1​∂c(w,y)​=w1​−ba​⋅w2​⋅A−b1​⋅yb1​⋅x1−ba+b​​=0

Step 4: Solving for conditional factor demands

The conditional factor demand for x1x_1x1​ is:

x1(w1,w2,y)=A−1a+b⋅(a⋅w2b⋅w1)ba+b⋅y1a+b x_1(w_1, w_2, y) = A^{-\frac{1}{a+b}} \cdot \left(\frac{a \cdot w_2}{b \cdot w_1}\right)^{\frac{b}{a+b}} \cdot y^{\frac{1}{a+b}} x1​(w1​,w2​,y)=A−a+b1​⋅(b⋅w1​a⋅w2​​)a+bb​⋅ya+b1​

Similarly, the conditional factor demand for x2x_2x2​ is:

x2(w1,w2,y)=A−1a+b⋅(a⋅w2b⋅w1)−aa+b⋅y1a+b x_2(w_1, w_2, y) = A^{-\frac{1}{a+b}} \cdot \left(\frac{a \cdot w_2}{b \cdot w_1}\right)^{-\frac{a}{a+b}} \cdot y^{\frac{1}{a+b}} x2​(w1​,w2​,y)=A−a+b1​⋅(b⋅w1​a⋅w2​​)−a+ba​⋅ya+b1​

Step 5: Cost function

The total cost function is obtained by substituting the conditional demands for x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ into the original cost function:

C(w1,w2,y)=A−1a+b[(ab)ba+b+(ab)−aa+b]w1aa+b⋅w2ba+b⋅y1a+b C(w_1, w_2, y) = A^{-\frac{1}{a+b}} \left[\left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^{\frac{b}{a+b}} + \left(\frac{a}{b}\right)^{-\frac{a}{a+b}}\right] w_1^{\frac{a}{a+b}} \cdot w_2^{\frac{b}{a+b}} \cdot y^{\frac{1}{a+b}} C(w1​,w2​,y)=A−a+b1​[(ba​)a+bb​+(ba​)−a+ba​]w1a+ba​​⋅w2a+bb​​⋅ya+b1​

Special Case: a+b=1a + b = 1a+b=1

When a+b=1a + b = 1a+b=1, the cost function simplifies to:

C(w1,w2,y)=K⋅w1a⋅w21−a⋅y C(w_1, w_2, y) = K \cdot w_1^a \cdot w_2^{1-a} \cdot y C(w1​,w2​,y)=K⋅w1a​⋅w21−a​⋅y

where the constant KKK is:

K=a−a⋅(1−a)−(1−a) K = a^{-a} \cdot (1-a)^{-(1-a)} K=a−a⋅(1−a)−(1−a)
The Cobb-Douglas production function, when subject to cost minimization, yields specific demand functions for the factors of production (x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​) and a cost function that reflects the input prices (w1w_1w1​, w2w_2w2​) and the output level (yyy).

2. Cost Function for the CES Technology

Let the CES production function be:
f(x1,x2)=(x1ρ+x2ρ)1ρf(x_1, x_2) = \left(x_1^\rho + x_2^\rho\right)^{\frac{1}{\rho}}f(x1​,x2​)=(x1ρ​+x2ρ​)ρ1​

Minimize w1x1+w2x2 s.t. x1ρ+x2ρ=yρw_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 \text{ s.t. } x_1^\rho + x_2^\rho = y^\rhow1​x1​+w2​x2​ s.t. x1ρ​+x2ρ​=yρ

The Lagrangian is:
L=w1x1+w2x2+λ[yρ−(x1ρ+x2ρ)]L = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 + \lambda \left[y^\rho - (x_1^\rho + x_2^\rho)\right]L=w1​x1​+w2​x2​+λ[yρ−(x1ρ​+x2ρ​)]

First-order conditions:
∂L∂x1=w1−λρx1ρ−1=0(1)\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_1} = w_1 - \lambda \rho x_1^{\rho-1} = 0 \quad \text{(1)}∂x1​∂L​=w1​−λρx1ρ−1​=0(1)
∂L∂x2=w2−λρx2ρ−1=0(2)\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_2} = w_2 - \lambda \rho x_2^{\rho-1} = 0 \quad \text{(2)}∂x2​∂L​=w2​−λρx2ρ−1​=0(2)
x1ρ+x2ρ=yρ(3)x_1^\rho + x_2^\rho = y^\rho \quad \text{(3)}x1ρ​+x2ρ​=yρ(3)

From (1) and (2), we get:
w1w2=x1ρ−1x2ρ−1\frac{w_1}{w_2} = \frac{x_1^{\rho-1}}{x_2^{\rho-1}}w2​w1​​=x2ρ−1​x1ρ−1​​
x1=x2⋅(w1w2)1ρ−1x_1 = x_2 \cdot \left(\frac{w_1}{w_2}\right)^{\frac{1}{\rho-1}}x1​=x2​⋅(w2​w1​​)ρ−11​

Substitute into the constraint (3):
x1ρ=x2ρ⋅(w1w2)ρρ−1x_1^\rho = x_2^\rho \cdot \left(\frac{w_1}{w_2}\right)^{\frac{\rho}{\rho-1}}x1ρ​=x2ρ​⋅(w2​w1​​)ρ−1ρ​

Thus:
x2ρ=(w2λρ)ρρ−1x_2^\rho = \left(\frac{w_2}{\lambda \rho}\right)^{\frac{\rho}{\rho-1}}x2ρ​=(λρw2​​)ρ−1ρ​
Similarly:
x1ρ=(w1λρ)ρρ−1x_1^\rho = \left(\frac{w_1}{\lambda \rho}\right)^{\frac{\rho}{\rho-1}}x1ρ​=(λρw1​​)ρ−1ρ​

Total cost:
c(w1,w2,y)=y[w1γ+w2γ]1γc(w_1, w_2, y) = y \left[w_1^\gamma + w_2^\gamma\right]^{\frac{1}{\gamma}}c(w1​,w2​,y)=y[w1γ​+w2γ​]γ1​
where γ=ρρ−1\gamma = \frac{\rho}{\rho-1}γ=ρ−1ρ​

3. Leontief Technology

The Leontief production function is:
f(x1,x2)=min⁡{ax1,bx2}f(x_1, x_2) = \min \{a x_1, b x_2\}f(x1​,x2​)=min{ax1​,bx2​}

Here, calculus is not useful as the firm wants to avoid wasting any input:
y=ax1=bx2y = a x_1 = b x_2y=ax1​=bx2​

The cost function is:
c=w1x1+w2x2c = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2c=w1​x1​+w2​x2​

Substitute x1=yax_1 = \frac{y}{a}x1​=ay​ and x2=ybx_2 = \frac{y}{b}x2​=by​:
c=w1ya+w2yb=y(w1a+w2b)c = \frac{w_1 y}{a} + \frac{w_2 y}{b} = y \left(\frac{w_1}{a} + \frac{w_2}{b}\right)c=aw1​y​+bw2​y​=y(aw1​​+bw2​​)

4. Substitutes

Production Function

For perfect substitutes, the production function is given by:

f(x1+x2)=ax1+bx2 f(x_1 + x_2) = a x_1 + b x_2 f(x1​+x2​)=ax1​+bx2​

Solving for the Cost Function

In this case, we don’t need calculus to solve for the cost function. Simple logic suffices. Since the two factors are perfect substitutes, the firm’s choice between them will be based on which factor is cheaper.

The cost function is:

c=min⁡{w1a,w2b}⋅y c = \min \left\{ \frac{w_1}{a}, \frac{w_2}{b} \right\} \cdot y c=min{aw1​​,bw2​​}⋅y

Why?

Let’s break it down:

  1. If w1=w2w_1 = w_2w1​=w2​, then the total cost ccc is:

c=w1x1+w2x2=w1x1+w1x2 c = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 = w_1 x_1 + w_1 x_2 c=w1​x1​+w2​x2​=w1​x1​+w1​x2​

  1. If w1<w2w_1 < w_2w1​<w2​, the firm uses only x1x_1x1​, since it is cheaper:

x1∗=ya x_1^* = \frac{y}{a} x1∗​=ay​

The optimal combination of x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ would be:

(x1+x2)=[0,ya]/w1=w2 (x_1 + x_2) = \left[ 0, \frac{y}{a} \right] / w_1 = w_2 (x1​+x2​)=[0,ay​]/w1​=w2​

Thus, x2∗=0x_2^* = 0x2∗​=0 if w2<w1w_2 < w_1w2​<w1​.

  1. If w2<w1w_2 < w_1w2​<w1​, the firm uses only x2x_2x2​, leading to:

x2∗=yb∀ w2<w1 x_2^* = \frac{y}{b} \quad \forall \, w_2 < w_1 x2∗​=by​∀w2​<w1​

  1. If w1=w2w_1 = w_2w1​=w2​, a combination of inputs can be used:

[ab,1] if w2=w1 \left[ \frac{a}{b}, 1 \right] \text{ if } w_2 = w_1 [ba​,1] if w2​=w1​

  1. If w1<w2w_1 < w_2w1​<w2​, x2=0x_2 = 0x2​=0:

x2=0 if w1<w2 x_2 = 0 \text{ if } w_1 < w_2 x2​=0 if w1​<w2​

Total Cost (TC)

For total cost:

  • If w1<w2w_1 < w_2w1​<w2​:

TC=w1ya TC = \frac{w_1 y}{a} TC=aw1​y​

  • If w2<w1w_2 < w_1w2​<w1​:

TC=w2yb TC = \frac{w_2 y}{b} TC=bw2​y​

Thus, the total cost function depends on the relationship between w1w_1w1​, w2w_2w2​, and the factors of production.

These examples illustrate that there is a relationship between the production technology and the cost function specification. The firm’s decision of input combination is dependent on which input is cheaper, and whether both inputs can be used simultaneously (as in the case of equal costs). Boundary solutions often occur, and these can be formally addressed using the Kuhn-Tucker theorem, which we will now explore.

Kuhn-Tucker Theorem: Optimization with Constraints

Problem Setup

Consider the following optimization problem:

Minimize
f(x)f(x)f(x)
subject to:
gj(x)≤0for j=1,2,…,pg_j(x) \leq 0 \quad \text{for } j = 1, 2, \dots, pgj​(x)≤0for j=1,2,…,p

where x=[x1,x2,…,xn]x = [x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n]x=[x1​,x2​,…,xn​].

Kuhn-Tucker Conditions

To find a local minimum for x∗=[x1∗,x2∗,…,xn∗]x^* = [x_1^*, x_2^*, \dots, x_n^*]x∗=[x1∗​,x2∗​,…,xn∗​], we use the following Kuhn-Tucker conditions.

Lagrangian Function

Define the Lagrangian function as:

L(x,λ)=f(x)+∑j=1pλj⋅gj(x) L(x, \lambda) = f(x) + \sum_{j=1}^{p} \lambda_j \cdot g_j(x) L(x,λ)=f(x)+j=1∑p​λj​⋅gj​(x)

Kuhn-Tucker Conditions

  1. Stationarity:
    For each i=1,…,ni = 1, \dots, ni=1,…,n:
    ∂L∂xi=∂f(x)∂xi+∑j=1pλj∂gj(x)∂xi=0 \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_i} = \frac{\partial f(x)}{\partial x_i} + \sum_{j=1}^{p} \lambda_j \frac{\partial g_j(x)}{\partial x_i} = 0 ∂xi​∂L​=∂xi​∂f(x)​+j=1∑p​λj​∂xi​∂gj​(x)​=0

  2. Primal feasibility:
    For each j=1,…,pj = 1, \dots, pj=1,…,p:
    gj(x)≤0 g_j(x) \leq 0 gj​(x)≤0

  3. Dual feasibility:
    For each j=1,…,pj = 1, \dots, pj=1,…,p:
    λj≥0 \lambda_j \geq 0 λj​≥0

  4. Complementary slackness:
    For each j=1,…,pj = 1, \dots, pj=1,…,p:
    λj⋅gj(x)=0 \lambda_j \cdot g_j(x) = 0 λj​⋅gj​(x)=0

Example Problem

Let’s now consider an example of applying the Kuhn-Tucker theorem to a real problem.

Problem:

  1. Objective Function:
    f(x1,x2,x3)=x12+2x22+3x32f(x_1, x_2, x_3) = x_1^2 + 2x_2^2 + 3x_3^2f(x1​,x2​,x3​)=x12​+2x22​+3x32​

    Subject to:

    g1=x1−x2−2x3≤12 g_1 = x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 \leq 12 g1​=x1​−x2​−2x3​≤12

    g2=x1+2x2−3x3≤8 g_2 = x_1 + 2x_2 - 3x_3 \leq 8 g2​=x1​+2x2​−3x3​≤8

  2. Lagrangian:
    The Lagrangian for this problem is:

    L=x12+2x22+3x32+λ1(x1−x2−2x3−12)+λ2(x1+2x2−3x3−8) L = x_1^2 + 2x_2^2 + 3x_3^2 + \lambda_1 (x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 - 12) + \lambda_2 (x_1 + 2x_2 - 3x_3 - 8) L=x12​+2x22​+3x32​+λ1​(x1​−x2​−2x3​−12)+λ2​(x1​+2x2​−3x3​−8)

Kuhn-Tucker Conditions:

From here, we derive the following conditions:

  • Stationarity:

∂L∂x1=2x1+λ1+λ2=0(1) \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_1} = 2x_1 + \lambda_1 + \lambda_2 = 0 \quad \text{(1)} ∂x1​∂L​=2x1​+λ1​+λ2​=0(1)

∂L∂x2=4x2−λ1+2λ2=0(2) \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_2} = 4x_2 - \lambda_1 + 2\lambda_2 = 0 \quad \text{(2)} ∂x2​∂L​=4x2​−λ1​+2λ2​=0(2)

∂L∂x3=6x3−2λ1−3λ2=0(3) \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_3} = 6x_3 - 2\lambda_1 - 3\lambda_2 = 0 \quad \text{(3)} ∂x3​∂L​=6x3​−2λ1​−3λ2​=0(3)

  • Primal Feasibility:

x1−x2−2x3−12≤0(4) x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 - 12 \leq 0 \quad \text{(4)} x1​−x2​−2x3​−12≤0(4)

x1+2x2−3x3−8≤0(5) x_1 + 2x_2 - 3x_3 - 8 \leq 0 \quad \text{(5)} x1​+2x2​−3x3​−8≤0(5)

  • Complementary Slackness:

λ1(x1−x2−2x3−12)=0(6) \lambda_1 (x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 - 12) = 0 \quad \text{(6)} λ1​(x1​−x2​−2x3​−12)=0(6)

λ2(x1+2x2−3x3−8)=0(7) \lambda_2 (x_1 + 2x_2 - 3x_3 - 8) = 0 \quad \text{(7)} λ2​(x1​+2x2​−3x3​−8)=0(7)

  • Dual Feasibility:

λ1≥0(8) \lambda_1 \geq 0 \quad \text{(8)} λ1​≥0(8)

λ2≥0(9) \lambda_2 \geq 0 \quad \text{(9)} λ2​≥0(9)

We have these nine equations and five unknowns - solvable.

From (6) →\rightarrow→ Either λ1=0\lambda_1 = 0λ1​=0 or (x1−x2−2x3−12)=0(x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 - 12) = 0(x1​−x2​−2x3​−12)=0.

Case I: λ1=0\lambda_1 = 0λ1​=0

From (1) →x1=−λ22\rightarrow x_1 = -\frac{\lambda_2}{2}→x1​=−2λ2​​

From (2) →x2=−λ22\rightarrow x_2 = -\frac{\lambda_2}{2}→x2​=−2λ2​​

From (3) →x3=λ22\rightarrow x_3 = \frac{\lambda_2}{2}→x3​=2λ2​​

Now, from (7) →λ2(x1+2x2−3x3−8)=0\rightarrow \lambda_2 (x_1 + 2x_2 - 3x_3 - 8) = 0→λ2​(x1​+2x2​−3x3​−8)=0:
λ2(−λ22−λ2−3λ22−8)=0. \lambda_2 \left(-\frac{\lambda_2}{2} - \lambda_2 - \frac{3 \lambda_2}{2} - 8\right) = 0. λ2​(−2λ2​​−λ2​−23λ2​​−8)=0.
This simplifies to:
λ22+8λ2=0. \lambda_2^2 + 8 \lambda_2 = 0. λ22​+8λ2​=0.
Thus, we have λ2=0\lambda_2 = 0λ2​=0 or λ2=−8\lambda_2 = -8λ2​=−8.

Consequently, λ2=x2=x3=0\lambda_2 = x_2 = x_3 = 0λ2​=x2​=x3​=0.

Since (4) →λ2≥0\rightarrow \lambda_2 \ge 0→λ2​≥0, we can verify that all equations (1) - (9) hold true.

So (0,0,0)(0, 0, 0)(0,0,0) satisfies all equations (1) - (9).

Case II: x1−x2−2x3=12x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 = 12x1​−x2​−2x3​=12

Using (1), (2), and (3):
x1=−(λ1+λ2)2,x2=λ1−2λ24,x3=2λ1+3λ26. x_1 = -\frac{(\lambda_1 + \lambda_2)}{2}, \quad x_2 = \frac{\lambda_1 - 2 \lambda_2}{4}, \quad x_3 = \frac{2 \lambda_1 + 3 \lambda_2}{6}. x1​=−2(λ1​+λ2​)​,x2​=4λ1​−2λ2​​,x3​=62λ1​+3λ2​​.
Substituting into x1−x2−2x3=12x_1 - x_2 - 2x_3 = 12x1​−x2​−2x3​=12 gives:
77λ1+19λ2=−144. 77 \lambda_1 + 19 \lambda_2 = -144. 77λ1​+19λ2​=−144.
This would require λ1\lambda_1λ1​ and λ2\lambda_2λ2​ to be negative, which violates (8) and (9). Hence, the only solution is (0,0,0)(0, 0, 0)(0,0,0).

Ex.2: Minimize
f(x1,x2)=x12+x22+60x1(16) f(x_1, x_2) = x_1^2 + x_2^2 + 60 x_1 \quad (16) f(x1​,x2​)=x12​+x22​+60x1​(16)
subject to the constraints
g1=x1−80≥0andg2=x1+x2−120≥0. g_1 = x_1 - 80 \ge 0 \quad \text{and} \quad g_2 = x_1 + x_2 - 120 \ge 0. g1​=x1​−80≥0andg2​=x1​+x2​−120≥0.

The Lagrangian function is:
L=x12+x22+60x1+λ1[−x1+80]+λ2[−x1−x2+120]. L = x_1^2 + x_2^2 + 60 x_1 + \lambda_1 [-x_1 + 80] + \lambda_2 [-x_1 - x_2 + 120]. L=x12​+x22​+60x1​+λ1​[−x1​+80]+λ2​[−x1​−x2​+120].

Kuhn Tucker conditions:

∂L∂x1=2x1+60−λ1−λ2=0⋯(1) \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_1} = 2 x_1 + 60 - \lambda_1 - \lambda_2 = 0 \quad \cdots (1) ∂x1​∂L​=2x1​+60−λ1​−λ2​=0⋯(1)

∂L∂x2=2x2−λ2=0⋯(2) \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_2} = 2 x_2 - \lambda_2 = 0 \quad \cdots (2) ∂x2​∂L​=2x2​−λ2​=0⋯(2)

∂L∂λ1=−x1+80≤0⋯(3) \frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_1} = -x_1 + 80 \le 0 \quad \cdots (3) ∂λ1​∂L​=−x1​+80≤0⋯(3)

∂L∂λ2=−x1−x2+120≤0⋯(4) \frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_2} = -x_1 - x_2 + 120 \le 0 \quad \cdots (4) ∂λ2​∂L​=−x1​−x2​+120≤0⋯(4)

∂L∂λ1=λ1(−x1+80)=0⋯(5) \frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_1} = \lambda_1 (-x_1 + 80) = 0 \quad \cdots (5) ∂λ1​∂L​=λ1​(−x1​+80)=0⋯(5)

∂L∂λ2=λ2(−x1−x2+120)=0⋯(6) \frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_2} = \lambda_2 (-x_1 - x_2 + 120) = 0 \quad \cdots (6) ∂λ2​∂L​=λ2​(−x1​−x2​+120)=0⋯(6)

λ1≥0⋯(7) \lambda_1 \ge 0 \quad \cdots (7) λ1​≥0⋯(7)

λ2≥0⋯(8) \lambda_2 \ge 0 \quad \cdots (8) λ2​≥0⋯(8)

Again, we have eight equations and four unknowns.

As always, we start from either of the λj∂L∂λj\lambda_j \frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_j}λj​∂λj​∂L​ equality constraints. Let’s start with (5) →λ1(−x1+80)=0\rightarrow \lambda_1 (-x_1 + 80) = 0→λ1​(−x1​+80)=0 (17).

Either λ1=0\lambda_1 = 0λ1​=0 or x1=80x_1 = 80x1​=80.

Case I: λ1=0\lambda_1 = 0λ1​=0

From (1) →x1=λ2−602\rightarrow x_1 = \frac{\lambda_2 - 60}{2}→x1​=2λ2​−60​.

From (2) →x2=λ22\rightarrow x_2 = \frac{\lambda_2}{2}→x2​=2λ2​​.

Thus, from (6) →λ2(−x1−x2+120)=0\rightarrow \lambda_2 (-x_1 - x_2 + 120) = 0→λ2​(−x1​−x2​+120)=0:
λ2(−(λ2−60)2−λ22+120)=0. \lambda_2 \left(-\frac{(\lambda_2 - 60)}{2} - \frac{\lambda_2}{2} + 120\right) = 0. λ2​(−2(λ2​−60)​−2λ2​​+120)=0.
This simplifies to:
λ2(−λ22+30−λ22+120)=0. \lambda_2 \left(-\frac{\lambda_2}{2} + 30 - \frac{\lambda_2}{2} + 120\right) = 0. λ2​(−2λ2​​+30−2λ2​​+120)=0.
Thus:
λ2(−λ22+150)=0. \lambda_2 \left(-\frac{\lambda_2}{2} + 150\right) = 0. λ2​(−2λ2​​+150)=0.

Therefore, λ2=0\lambda_2 = 0λ2​=0 or λ2=300\lambda_2 = 300λ2​=300.

Continuing the solution using the previous method.

Let us apply this non negative inequality constraint to one of our examples of cost function:

Perfect Substitutes:

Consider the cost function for a linear production technology:

→ Minimize w1x1+w2x2w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2w1​x1​+w2​x2​ subject to the constraints x1≥0x_1 \ge 0x1​≥0 and x2≥0x_2 \ge 0x2​≥0.

The Lagrangian can be expressed as:

L=w1x1+w2x2+λ1[y−x1−x2]+λ2x1+λ3x2 L = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 + \lambda_1 [y - x_1 - x_2] + \lambda_2 x_1 + \lambda_3 x_2 L=w1​x1​+w2​x2​+λ1​[y−x1​−x2​]+λ2​x1​+λ3​x2​

To find the optimal values, we derive the following first-order conditions:

  1. ∂L∂x1=0→w1−λ1+λ2=0(1)\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_1} = 0 \rightarrow w_1 - \lambda_1 + \lambda_2 = 0 \quad \text{(1)}∂x1​∂L​=0→w1​−λ1​+λ2​=0(1)

  2. ∂L∂x2=0→w2−λ1+λ3=0(2)\frac{\partial L}{\partial x_2} = 0 \rightarrow w_2 - \lambda_1 + \lambda_3 = 0 \quad \text{(2)}∂x2​∂L​=0→w2​−λ1​+λ3​=0(2)

  3. ∂L∂λ1=y−x1−x2=0(3)\frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_1} = y - x_1 - x_2 = 0 \quad \text{(3)}∂λ1​∂L​=y−x1​−x2​=0(3)

  4. ∂L∂λ2=x1≥0(4)\frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_2} = x_1 \ge 0 \quad \text{(4)}∂λ2​∂L​=x1​≥0(4)

  5. ∂L∂λ3=x2≥0(5)\frac{\partial L}{\partial \lambda_3} = x_2 \ge 0 \quad \text{(5)}∂λ3​∂L​=x2​≥0(5)

  6. λ2x1=0(6)\lambda_2 x_1 = 0 \quad \text{(6)}λ2​x1​=0(6)

  7. λ3x2=0(7)\lambda_3 x_2 = 0 \quad \text{(7)}λ3​x2​=0(7)

  8. λ2≤0(8)\lambda_2 \le 0 \quad \text{(8)}λ2​≤0(8)

  9. λ3≤0(9)\lambda_3 \le 0 \quad \text{(9)}λ3​≤0(9)

Case Analysis:

When λ2x1=0\lambda_2 x_1 = 0λ2​x1​=0, we have two possibilities: either λ2=0\lambda_2 = 0λ2​=0 or x1=0x_1 = 0x1​=0 (19). Similarly, when λ3x2=0\lambda_3 x_2 = 0λ3​x2​=0, it follows that either λ3=0\lambda_3 = 0λ3​=0 or x2=0x_2 = 0x2​=0.

Based on conditions (4) and (5), we can categorize into four distinct cases:

  1. Case (i): x1>0x_1 > 0x1​>0 and x2>0x_2 > 0x2​>0

    • Here, λ2=0\lambda_2 = 0λ2​=0 (from (6)) and λ3=0\lambda_3 = 0λ3​=0 (from (7)).
    • From (1): w1=λ1w_1 = \lambda_1w1​=λ1​
    • From (2): w2=λ1w_2 = \lambda_1w2​=λ1​
    • Hence, we find that w1=w2w_1 = w_2w1​=w2​.
    • The total cost becomes:
      c=w1x1+w2x2=w1(x1+x2)=w1y.c = w_1 x_1 + w_2 x_2 = w_1 (x_1 + x_2) = w_1 y.c=w1​x1​+w2​x2​=w1​(x1​+x2​)=w1​y.

  2. Case (ii): x1=0x_1 = 0x1​=0 and x2>0x_2 > 0x2​>0

    • From (3): y=x2y = x_2y=x2​
    • From (7): λ3=0\lambda_3 = 0λ3​=0
    • From (2): λ1=w2\lambda_1 = w_2λ1​=w2​
    • From (1): w1−w2+λ2=0w_1 - w_2 + \lambda_2 = 0w1​−w2​+λ2​=0
    • Rearranging gives: λ2=−(w1−w2)\lambda_2 = -(w_1 - w_2)λ2​=−(w1​−w2​)
    • The condition −(w1−w2)≤0-(w_1 - w_2) \le 0−(w1​−w2​)≤0 leads to: w1≥w2w_1 \ge w_2w1​≥w2​
    • Thus, the total cost becomes:
      c=w2y.c = w_2 y.c=w2​y.

  3. Case (iii): x1>0x_1 > 0x1​>0 and x2=0x_2 = 0x2​=0

    • By similar reasoning as Case (ii), we find that w2≥w1w_2 \ge w_1w2​≥w1​ and the cost becomes:
      c=w1y.c = w_1 y.c=w1​y.

  4. Case (iv): x1=0x_1 = 0x1​=0 and x2>0x_2 > 0x2​>0

    • Here, both (6) and (7) imply λ2=0\lambda_2 = 0λ2​=0 and λ3=0\lambda_3 = 0λ3​=0.
    • From (1): w1=λ1w_1 = \lambda_1w1​=λ1​
    • From (2): w2=λ1w_2 = \lambda_1w2​=λ1​
    • Therefore, we conclude that w1=w2w_1 = w_2w1​=w2​.

CONDITIONAL FACTOR DEMAND FUNCTIONS

The conditional factor demand functions are denoted by x(w,y)x(w,y)x(w,y). These functions specify the quantity of factors demanded (like labor or capital) based on their prices (www) and the level of output (yyy).

It must satisfy the first order conditions:

f(x(w,y))=y f(x(w,y)) = y f(x(w,y))=y
This equation states that the output yyy is produced using the factors x(w,y)x(w,y)x(w,y), as defined by the production function fff.

w−λ∇f(x(w,y))≡0 w - \lambda \nabla f(x(w,y)) \equiv 0 w−λ∇f(x(w,y))≡0
This represents the condition that the marginal cost of input (www) equals the marginal product of the input (∇f(x(w,y))\nabla f(x(w,y))∇f(x(w,y))) scaled by the shadow price (λ\lambdaλ).

Let us consider a two-good example:

x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​.

F.O.Cs can be written as:

f(x1(w1,w2,y),x2(w1,w2,y))≡y f(x_1(w_1,w_2,y),x_2(w_1,w_2,y)) \equiv y f(x1​(w1​,w2​,y),x2​(w1​,w2​,y))≡y
Here, the production function combines two factors (x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​) to produce output yyy.

w1−λ∂f(x1(w1,w2,y),x2(w1,w2,y))∂x1≡0 w_1 - \lambda \frac{\partial f(x_1(w_1,w_2,y),x_2(w_1,w_2,y))}{\partial x_1} \equiv 0 w1​−λ∂x1​∂f(x1​(w1​,w2​,y),x2​(w1​,w2​,y))​≡0
This shows the relationship between the price of factor x1x_1x1​ (w1w_1w1​) and its marginal product.

w2−λ∂f(x1(w1,w2,y),x2(w1,w2,y))∂x2≡0 w_2 - \lambda \frac{\partial f(x_1(w_1,w_2,y),x_2(w_1,w_2,y))}{\partial x_2} \equiv 0 w2​−λ∂x2​∂f(x1​(w1​,w2​,y),x2​(w1​,w2​,y))​≡0
Similarly, this condition applies to factor x2x_2x2​ and its price w2w_2w2​.

Let us try some comparative static analysis. What happens when w1w_1w1​ changes?

∂f∂x1⋅∂x1∂w1+∂f∂x2⋅∂x2∂w1≡0 \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \cdot \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} + \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} \equiv 0 ∂x1​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂x1​​+∂x2​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂x2​​≡0
This equation examines how a change in the price of factor x1x_1x1​ affects the quantities demanded of both x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​.

1−λ(∂2f∂x12⋅∂x1∂w1+∂2f∂x1∂x2⋅∂x2∂w1)−∂f∂x1⋅∂λ∂w1≡0 1 - \lambda \left(\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1^2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} + \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1}\right) - \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \cdot \frac{\partial \lambda}{\partial w_1} \equiv 0 1−λ(∂x12​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x1​​+∂x1​∂x2​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x2​​)−∂x1​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂λ​≡0
This condition accounts for second-order effects and the sensitivity of λ\lambdaλ to changes in w1w_1w1​.

0−λ(∂2f∂x2∂x1⋅∂x1∂w1+∂2f∂x22⋅∂x2∂w1)−∂f∂x2⋅∂λ∂w1≡0 0 - \lambda \left(\frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2 \partial x_1} \cdot \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} + \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2^2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1}\right) - \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot \frac{\partial \lambda}{\partial w_1} \equiv 0 0−λ(∂x2​∂x1​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x1​​+∂x22​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x2​​)−∂x2​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂λ​≡0
This mirrors the previous equation for factor x2x_2x2​.

0=∂f∂x1⋅∂x1∂w1−∂f∂x2⋅∂x2∂w1=0 0 = \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \cdot \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} - \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} = 0 0=∂x1​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂x1​​−∂x2​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂x2​​=0
This condition confirms that the total effect is zero.

−∂f∂x1⋅∂λ∂w1−λ⋅∂2f∂x12⋅∂x1∂w1−λ⋅∂2f∂x1∂x2⋅∂x2∂w1≡−1 -\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_1} \cdot \frac{\partial \lambda}{\partial w_1} - \lambda \cdot \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1^2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} - \lambda \cdot \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} \equiv -1 −∂x1​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂λ​−λ⋅∂x12​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x1​​−λ⋅∂x1​∂x2​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x2​​≡−1
This captures the response of the system to a change in w1w_1w1​, showing the adjustments in both factors and their marginal products.

−∂f∂x2⋅∂λ∂w1−λ⋅∂2f∂x2∂x1⋅∂x1∂w1−λ⋅∂2f∂x22⋅∂x2∂w1≡0 -\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_2} \cdot \frac{\partial \lambda}{\partial w_1} - \lambda \cdot \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2 \partial x_1} \cdot \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} - \lambda \cdot \frac{\partial^2 f}{\partial x_2^2} \cdot \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} \equiv 0 −∂x2​∂f​⋅∂w1​∂λ​−λ⋅∂x2​∂x1​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x1​​−λ⋅∂x22​∂2f​⋅∂w1​∂x2​​≡0
Similar to the previous condition, this one describes the changes for factor x2x_2x2​.

Writing these in matrix form:

[0−f1−f2−f1−λf11−λf12−f2−λf21−λf22][∂λ∂w1∂x1∂w1∂x2∂w1]=[0−10] \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -f_1 & -f_2 \\ -f_1 & -\lambda f_{11} & -\lambda f_{12} \\ -f_2 & -\lambda f_{21} & -\lambda f_{22} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \frac{\partial \lambda}{\partial w_1} \\ \frac{\partial x_1}{\partial w_1} \\ \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} ⎣⎡​0−f1​−f2​​−f1​−λf11​−λf21​​−f2​−λf12​−λf22​​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​∂w1​∂λ​∂w1​∂x1​​∂w1​∂x2​​​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​0−10​⎦⎤​
This matrix representation organizes the system of equations for easier manipulation and solution.

Using Cramer’s rule:

∂λ∂w1=∣0−f1−f2−1−λf11−λf120−λf21−λf22∣∣0−f1−f2−f1−λf11−λf12−f2−λf21−λf22∣=f22H<0 \frac{\partial \lambda}{\partial w_1} = \frac{\begin{vmatrix} 0 & -f_1 & -f_2 \\ -1 & -\lambda f_{11} & -\lambda f_{12} \\ 0 & -\lambda f_{21} & -\lambda f_{22} \end{vmatrix}}{\begin{vmatrix} 0 & -f_1 & -f_2 \\ -f_1 & -\lambda f_{11} & -\lambda f_{12} \\ -f_2 & -\lambda f_{21} & -\lambda f_{22} \end{vmatrix}} = \frac{f_2^2}{H} < 0 ∂w1​∂λ​=∣∣​0−f1​−f2​​−f1​−λf11​−λf21​​−f2​−λf12​−λf22​​∣∣​∣∣​0−10​−f1​−λf11​−λf21​​−f2​−λf12​−λf22​​∣∣​​=Hf22​​<0
This shows how the shadow price (λ\lambdaλ) changes with respect to the wage of factor x1x_1x1​, with a negative sign indicating that an increase in w1w_1w1​ reduces λ\lambdaλ.

Similarly,

∂x2∂w1=−f1f2H>0 \frac{\partial x_2}{\partial w_1} = \frac{-f_1 f_2}{H} > 0 ∂w1​∂x2​​=H−f1​f2​​>0
This indicates that as the wage of factor x1x_1x1​ increases, the quantity of factor x2x_2x2​ demanded also increases, reflecting a substitutive relationship.

The sign of the cross price effect is positive. This implies that the two factors are substitutes.

A word of caution: It is only in this two-factor case that we get the cross price effect to be positive. In a more general framework with more goods, this term can have a negative or a positive sign.

VECTOR NOTATION:

f(x(w))=y→F.O.Cs f(x(w)) = y \quad \rightarrow \quad \text{F.O.Cs} f(x(w))=y→F.O.Cs
This notation summarizes the relationship between factor inputs and output.

w−λ∇f(x(w))=0 w - \lambda \nabla f(x(w)) = 0 w−λ∇f(x(w))=0

Differentiating w.r.t. www:

∇f(x(w))⋅Dx(w)≡0 \nabla f(x(w)) \cdot D x(w) \equiv 0 ∇f(x(w))⋅Dx(w)≡0
This derivative indicates that the change in the factor demand due to changes in wages must equal zero, maintaining equilibrium.

I−λ⋅∇2f(x(w))⋅Dx(w)−∇f(x(w))⋅∇λ(w)≡0 I - \lambda \cdot \nabla^2 f(x(w)) \cdot D x(w) - \nabla f(x(w)) \cdot \nabla \lambda(w) \equiv 0 I−λ⋅∇2f(x(w))⋅Dx(w)−∇f(x(w))⋅∇λ(w)≡0
This equation considers the second derivatives of the production function and the effects of changes in λ\lambdaλ.

For Matrix arrangement:

[0−∇f(x)−∇f(x)T−λ⋅∇2f(x)][∇λ(w)Dx(w)]=[0I] \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -\nabla f(x) \\ -\nabla f(x)^T & -\lambda \cdot \nabla^2 f(x) \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \nabla \lambda(w) \\ D x(w) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ I \end{bmatrix} [0−∇f(x)T​−∇f(x)−λ⋅∇2f(x)​][∇λ(w)Dx(w)​]=[0I​]

[∇λ(w)Dx(w)]=[0−∇f(x)−∇f(x)T−λ⋅∇2f(x)]−1⋅[0I] \begin{bmatrix} \nabla \lambda(w) \\ D x(w) \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -\nabla f(x) \\ -\nabla f(x)^T & -\lambda \cdot \nabla^2 f(x) \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \cdot \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ I \end{bmatrix} [∇λ(w)Dx(w)​]=[0−∇f(x)T​−∇f(x)−λ⋅∇2f(x)​]−1⋅[0I​]
This representation allows for the calculation of changes in both λ\lambdaλ and factor demands using matrix algebra.

x(w)=(Dx(w),Dy(w)) x(w) = \left( D_x(w), D_y(w) \right) x(w)=(Dx​(w),Dy​(w))

ALGEBRAIC APPROACH TO COST MINIMIZATION

Similar to the profit maximization analysis, we can apply algebraic techniques to cost minimization.

Observed Choices by a Firm

We begin by considering the data that represents the choices made by a firm:

  • Output Levels:
    ytfor t=1,…,T y^t \quad \text{for } t=1, \ldots, T ytfor t=1,…,T

  • Price Levels:
    wtfor t=1,…,T w^t \quad \text{for } t=1, \ldots, T wtfor t=1,…,T

  • Factor Levels:
    xtfor t=1,…,T x^t \quad \text{for } t=1, \ldots, T xtfor t=1,…,T

Conditions for Cost Minimization

This data is consistent with the behavior of cost minimization when:

wtxt≤wtxs∀s such that ys≥yt w^t x^t \leq w^t x^s \quad \forall s \text{ such that } y^s \geq y^t wtxt≤wtxs∀s such that ys≥yt

This principle is known as the Weak Axiom of Cost Minimization (WACM).

Analyzing Two Different Observations with the Same Output Levels

For two different observations that produce the same output levels, we have:

wtxt≤wtxs w^t x^t \leq w^t x^s wtxt≤wtxs

wsxs≤wsxt w^s x^s \leq w^s x^t wsxs≤wsxt

By rearranging these inequalities, we get:

−wsxt≤−wsxs -w^s x^t \leq -w^s x^s −wsxt≤−wsxs

Adding the Inequalities

Combining the inequalities gives:

(wt−ws)xt≤(wt−ws)xs (w^t - w^s)x^t \leq (w^t - w^s)x^s (wt−ws)xt≤(wt−ws)xs

From this, we can conclude:

(wt−ws)(xt−xs)≤0 (w^t - w^s)(x^t - x^s) \leq 0 (wt−ws)(xt−xs)≤0

Conclusion

The final implication is:

ΔwΔx≤0 \Delta w \Delta x \leq 0 ΔwΔx≤0

This means that the vector of factor demands must move in the opposite direction of the vector of factor prices. In other words, if the prices of factors increase, the quantity demanded of those factors should decrease, and vice versa.

Chapter 5 - COST FUNCTION

The cost function measures the minimum cost of producing a given level of output for specified factor prices. It provides essential information about the technological choices available to the firm.

Just as the production function serves as the primary means of describing the technological possibilities of a firm, the cost function is our main tool for describing the economic possibilities of a firm.

In this chapter, we will examine the behavior of the cost function c(w,y)c(w, y)c(w,y) with respect to its arguments. Before diving in, let’s quickly revise some related concepts!

AVERAGE AND MARGINAL COSTS

Let’s consider the structure of the cost function:

c(w,y)=w⋅x(w,y) c(w, y) = w \cdot x(w, y) c(w,y)=w⋅x(w,y)

This function represents the cheapest way to produce yyy units of output, taking into account the time concept, which can be short-run (SR) or long-run (LR).

In the Short Run (SR)

In the short run, some factors of production are fixed.

  • Let xfx_fxf​ represent the vector of fixed factors.
  • Let xvx_vxv​ represent the vector of variable factors.
  • w=(wv,wf)w = (w_v, w_f)w=(wv​,wf​) denotes the vector of prices for variable and fixed factors.

The short-run conditional factor demand will depend on xfx_fxf​, leading us to:

xv=xv(w,y,xf) x_v = x_v(w, y, x_f) xv​=xv​(w,y,xf​)

The short-run cost function can be expressed as:

c(w,y,xf)=wv⋅xv(w,y,xf)+wf⋅xf c(w, y, x_f) = w_v \cdot x_v(w, y, x_f) + w_f \cdot x_f c(w,y,xf​)=wv​⋅xv​(w,y,xf​)+wf​⋅xf​

From the short-run cost function, we derive the following:

  • Short-run variable cost:
    Variable Cost=wv⋅xv(w,y,xf) \text{Variable Cost} = w_v \cdot x_v(w, y, x_f) Variable Cost=wv​⋅xv​(w,y,xf​)

  • Fixed cost:
    Fixed Cost=wf⋅xf \text{Fixed Cost} = w_f \cdot x_f Fixed Cost=wf​⋅xf​

  • Short-run average cost (SR AC):
    SR AC=c(w,y,xf)y=wv⋅xv(w,y,xf)+wf⋅xfy \text{SR AC} = \frac{c(w, y, x_f)}{y} = \frac{w_v \cdot x_v(w, y, x_f) + w_f \cdot x_f}{y} SR AC=yc(w,y,xf​)​=ywv​⋅xv​(w,y,xf​)+wf​⋅xf​​

  • Short-run average variable cost (SR AVC):
    SR AVC=wv⋅xv(w,y,xf)y \text{SR AVC} = \frac{w_v \cdot x_v(w, y, x_f)}{y} SR AVC=ywv​⋅xv​(w,y,xf​)​

  • Short-run average fixed cost (SR AFC):
    SR AFC=wf⋅xfy \text{SR AFC} = \frac{w_f \cdot x_f}{y} SR AFC=ywf​⋅xf​​

  • Short-run marginal cost (SR MC):
    SR MC=∂c∂y=∂c(w,y,xf)∂y \text{SR MC} = \frac{\partial c}{\partial y} = \frac{\partial c(w, y, x_f)}{\partial y} SR MC=∂y∂c​=∂y∂c(w,y,xf​)​

In the Long Run (LR)

In the long run, all factors of production are variable, and the cost function depends solely on www and yyy.

Let xf∗(w,y)x_f^*(w, y)xf∗​(w,y) be the optimal choice of the fixed factor, and xv(w,y)=xv(w,y,xf(w,y))x_v(w, y) = x_v(w, y, x_f(w, y))xv​(w,y)=xv​(w,y,xf​(w,y)) indicates the long-run optimal choice of the variable factor. Thus, the long-run cost function is expressed as:

c(w,y)=wv⋅xv(w,y)+wf⋅xf(w,y)=c(w,y,xf(w,y)) c(w, y) = w_v \cdot x_v(w, y) + w_f \cdot x_f(w, y) = c(w, y, x_f(w, y)) c(w,y)=wv​⋅xv​(w,y)+wf​⋅xf​(w,y)=c(w,y,xf​(w,y))

The long-run average cost (LAC) and long-run marginal cost (LMC) are defined as:

  • Long-run average cost (LAC):
    LAC=c(w,y)y \text{LAC} = \frac{c(w, y)}{y} LAC=yc(w,y)​

  • Long-run marginal cost (LMC):
    LMC=∂c(w,y)∂y \text{LMC} = \frac{\partial c(w, y)}{\partial y} LMC=∂y∂c(w,y)​

Note that in the long run, the short-run average cost (SR AC) equals the short-run average variable cost (SR AVC) since all costs are variable.

Short-Run Cobb-Douglas Cost Functions

The cost-minimizing problem for the production function y=x1a⋅k1−ay = x_1^a \cdot k^{1-a}y=x1a​⋅k1−a, assuming kkk to be fixed, can be stated as:

c(w,y,k)=Min w1x1+w2ks.t.y=x1a⋅k1−a c(w, y, k) = \text{Min } w_1 x_1 + w_2 k \quad \text{s.t.} \quad y = x_1^a \cdot k^{1-a} c(w,y,k)=Min w1​x1​+w2​ks.t.y=x1a​⋅k1−a

Setting up the Lagrangian:

L=w1x1+w2k+λ[y−x1a⋅k1−a] L = w_1 x_1 + w_2 k + \lambda [y - x_1^a \cdot k^{1-a}] L=w1​x1​+w2​k+λ[y−x1a​⋅k1−a]

Since it is a single variable factor, we can express:

x1=(yk1−a)1a x_1 = \left(\frac{y}{k^{1-a}}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}} x1​=(k1−ay​)a1​

Substituting this into the cost function gives:

c(w1,w2,y,k)=w1(yk1−a)1a+w2k c(w_1, w_2, y, k) = w_1 \left(\frac{y}{k^{1-a}}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}} + w_2 k c(w1​,w2​,y,k)=w1​(k1−ay​)a1​+w2​k

Calculating the short-run average cost (SR AC):

SR AC=w1(yk1−a)1ay+w2ky \text{SR AC} = \frac{w_1 \left(\frac{y}{k^{1-a}}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}}{y} + \frac{w_2 k}{y} SR AC=yw1​(k1−ay​)a1​​+yw2​k​

The short-run average variable cost (SR AVC) is:

SR AVC=w1(yk1−a)1ay \text{SR AVC} = \frac{w_1 \left(\frac{y}{k^{1-a}}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}}}{y} SR AVC=yw1​(k1−ay​)a1​​

The short-run marginal cost (SR MC) is given by:

SR MC=w1a⋅(yk1−a)1a−1 \text{SR MC} = \frac{w_1}{a} \cdot \left(\frac{y}{k^{1-a}}\right)^{\frac{1}{a}-1} SR MC=aw1​​⋅(k1−ay​)a1​−1

How Does Constant Returns to Scale (CRS) Affect the Cost Function?

If the production function exhibits constant returns to scale (CRS), then for capital and labor increasing by the same amount, the cost also increases by the same amount. Thus, the cost function is linear in the level of output:

c(w,y)=y⋅c(w) c(w, y) = y \cdot c(w) c(w,y)=y⋅c(w)

Proof: Let x∗x^*x∗ be the cheapest way to produce 1 unit of output at prices www. So,

c(w,1)=wx∗ c(w, 1) = wx^* c(w,1)=wx∗

What is c(w,y)c(w, y)c(w,y)?

Notice that y⋅x∗y \cdot x^*y⋅x∗ is feasible to produce yyy since the technology is CRS.

Let us assume that c(w,y)⋅x∗c(w, y) \cdot x^*c(w,y)⋅x∗ does not minimize the cost c(w,y)c(w, y)c(w,y) for yyy units of output at prices www. Instead, let z∗z^*z∗ be the cost-minimizing bundle to produce yyy at price www.

Then,

c(w,y)=x∗w<wyz∗ c(w,y) = x^*w < wy z^* c(w,y)=x∗w<wyz∗

This implies:

wxy<wx \frac{wx}{y} < wx ywx​<wx

But this contradicts the cost-minimizing condition for producing 1 unit of output. Hence, the only way this is satisfied is if wyx∗wy x^*wyx∗ is the cost-minimizing cost for producing yyy at prices www.

Thus, the cost function is linear in yyy, proving that if we have CRS, then:

AC=AVC=MC \text{AC} = \text{AVC} = \text{MC} AC=AVC=MC

Geometry of Costs

Properties of the Cost Function

The cost function exhibits different properties under varying conditions of factor prices:

  1. Fixed Factor Prices: In this scenario, costs depend solely on output. The total cost curve is assumed to be monotonic, meaning that as production increases, total costs also increase.

    • The average cost curve can either increase or decrease with output, depending on whether total costs rise more than or less than linearly.

  2. Variable Factor Prices: When prices are free to vary, the relationship between output and cost changes dynamically.

Short-Run Cost Function

In the short run (SR), the average cost behaves differently due to its two components: fixed costs and variable costs.

  • The average cost (AC) can be expressed as:

SAC=c(w,y,xf)y=wfxf+wvxv(w,y,xf)y=SAFC+SAVC \text{SAC} = \frac{c(w, y, x_f)}{y} = \frac{w_f x_f + w_v x_v(w, y, x_f)}{y} = \text{SAFC} + \text{SAVC} SAC=yc(w,y,xf​)​=ywf​xf​+wv​xv​(w,y,xf​)​=SAFC+SAVC

  • Short-run average fixed cost (SAFC) decreases as output increases, as fixed costs are spread over more units.

  • Short-run average variable cost (SAVC) is typically U-shaped due to the principle of variable proportions:

    1. Increasing Returns: Initially, as more of the variable factor is used, the SAVC falls because less input is required for each additional unit of output.

    2. Constant Returns: At some level of output, the SAVC remains constant.

    3. Decreasing Returns: Eventually, as more of the variable factor is added, the SAVC rises due to diminishing marginal returns.

Combining SAFC and SAVC results in the overall average cost (AC). Initially, AC decreases because of the decreasing SAFC and SAVC. However, after a certain point, the increasing SAVC causes the overall AC to rise.

The output level at which average cost is minimized is referred to as the minimal efficient scale.

Long-Run Cost Function

In the long run (LR), all costs are variable. Therefore, the phenomenon of increasing average costs seems unreasonable since a firm can replicate its production process efficiently without facing the constraints present in the short run.

In conclusion, understanding the geometry of costs helps firms determine the optimal level of production and pricing strategies while considering both fixed and variable factors.

Long-Run (LR) and Short-Run (SR) Cost Curves

Relationship Between LR and SR Cost Curves

The LR cost curve can never be above any SR cost curve because, in the LR, even fixed factors can be adjusted. This leads to unconstrained optimization, which results in better outcomes.

The LR cost function can be expressed as:

c(y)=c(y,z(y)) c(y) = c(y, z(y)) c(y)=c(y,z(y))

Here, let z(y)z(y)z(y) represent the cost-minimizing demand for a single fixed factor.

For a given amount of output, let y∗y^*y∗ be defined as follows:

  • z∗=z(y∗)z^* = z(y^*)z∗=z(y∗): This is the LR demand for the fixed factor associated with output y∗y^*y∗.

The SR cost, given by c(y,z∗)c(y, z^*)c(y,z∗), must be at least as large as the LR cost for producing y∗y^*y∗:

c(y∗,z∗)=c(y∗,z(y∗)) c(y^*, z^*) = c(y^*, z(y^*)) c(y∗,z∗)=c(y∗,z(y∗))

Thus, the LR and SR cost curves must be tangent at the point y∗y^*y∗.

Geometric Restatement of the Envelope Theorem

The slope of the LR cost curve at y∗y^*y∗ can be expressed as:

dc(y∗,z(y∗))dy=∂c(y∗,z∗)∂y+∂c(y∗,z∗)∂z⋅∂z(y∗)∂y \frac{dc(y^*, z(y^*))}{dy} = \frac{\partial c(y^*, z^*)}{\partial y} + \frac{\partial c(y^*, z^*)}{\partial z} \cdot \frac{\partial z(y^*)}{\partial y} dydc(y∗,z(y∗))​=∂y∂c(y∗,z∗)​+∂z∂c(y∗,z∗)​⋅∂y∂z(y∗)​

Since ∂z(y∗)∂y=0\frac{\partial z(y^*)}{\partial y} = 0∂y∂z(y∗)​=0, we simplify this to:

dc(y∗,z(y∗))dy=∂c(y∗,z∗)∂y \frac{dc(y^*, z(y^*))}{dy} = \frac{\partial c(y^*, z^*)}{\partial y} dydc(y∗,z(y∗))​=∂y∂c(y∗,z∗)​

Therefore, if the total cost curves in the SR and the LR are tangent to each other, the LR and SR average cost (AC) curves must also be tangent.

Family of Short-Run Average Cost (SRAC) Curves

Consider a family of SRAC curves corresponding to a fixed factor zzz. Let zzz take three possible values: z1z_1z1​, z2z_2z2​, and z3z_3z3​. The associated SRACs are denoted as SAC1SAC_1SAC1​, SAC2SAC_2SAC2​, and SAC3SAC_3SAC3​.

The LR average cost (LAC) for this family of SAC curves is the lower envelope of these SR cost curves. This is because the optimal choice of zzz to produce yyy is the choice that minimizes the cost of producing yyy.

Consequently, the LAC curve will have a scallop shape, representing the lower envelope of the SRAC curves.

Factor Prices and Cost Functions

In this section, we analyze the behavior of cost functions with respect to prices. Several interesting properties can be derived for the cost function, similar to those of the profit function:

1. Non-Decreasing in w

If w′>ww' > ww′>w, then c(w′,y)>c(w,y)c(w', y) > c(w, y)c(w′,y)>c(w,y).

Proof: Let xxx and zzz be the cost-minimizing bundles associated with prices www and w′w'w′, respectively. We have:

wx≤wzandw′z≤w′x′. wx \leq wz \quad \text{and} \quad w'z \leq w'x'. wx≤wzandw′z≤w′x′.

Since w≤w′w \leq w'w≤w′, it follows that:

wz≤w′z. wz \leq w'z. wz≤w′z.

Combining all the inequalities, we get:

wx≤w′x′. wx \leq w'x'. wx≤w′x′.

This completes the proof.

2. Homogeneous of Degree 1 in w

c(tw,y)=tc(w,y)for t>0. c(tw, y) = tc(w, y) \quad \text{for } t > 0. c(tw,y)=tc(w,y)for t>0.

Proof: If xxx is the cost-minimizing bundle at price www, then xxx also minimizes cost at price twtwtw. Suppose this is not the case. Let x′x'x′ be the bundle that minimizes cost at price twtwtw. Then:

x′(tw)≤x(tw)  ⟹  twx′≤twx. x'(tw) \leq x(tw) \implies twx' \leq twx. x′(tw)≤x(tw)⟹twx′≤twx.

This contradicts the assumption that xxx minimizes cost at price www. Hence, the proof is complete.

3. Concave in w

The following inequality holds:

c(tw+(1−t)w′)≥tc(w,y)+(1−t)c(w′,y)for 0≤t≤1. c(tw + (1-t)w') \geq t c(w, y) + (1-t) c(w', y) \quad \text{for } 0 \leq t \leq 1. c(tw+(1−t)w′)≥tc(w,y)+(1−t)c(w′,y)for 0≤t≤1.

Proof: Let (w,x)(w, x)(w,x) and (w′,x′)(w', x')(w′,x′) be two cost-minimizing price-factor combinations for producing yyy. Let w′′=tw+(1−t)w′w'' = tw + (1-t)w'w′′=tw+(1−t)w′ for 0≤t≤10 \leq t \leq 10≤t≤1.

Now, since w′′x′′w''x''w′′x′′ and w=tw+(1−t)w′′w = tw + (1-t)w''w=tw+(1−t)w′′, we have:

wx′′≥wxandw′x′′≥w′x′. wx'' \geq wx \quad \text{and} \quad w'x'' \geq w'x'. wx′′≥wxandw′x′′≥w′x′.

Thus, we get:

twx′′≥twxand(1−t)w′x′′≥(1−t)w′x′. twx'' \geq twx \quad \text{and} \quad (1-t)w'x'' \geq (1-t)w'x'. twx′′≥twxand(1−t)w′x′′≥(1−t)w′x′.

Combining these inequalities yields:

twx′′+(1−t)w′x′′≥twx+(1−t)w′x′. twx'' + (1-t)w'x'' \geq twx + (1-t)w'x'. twx′′+(1−t)w′x′′≥twx+(1−t)w′x′.

This implies:

c(w′′,y)≥tc(w,y)+(1−t)c(w′,y). c(w'', y) \geq t c(w, y) + (1-t) c(w', y). c(w′′,y)≥tc(w,y)+(1−t)c(w′,y).

Hence, the proof is complete.

4. Continuous in w

The function C(w,y)C(w, y)C(w,y) is continuous for w>0w > 0w>0.

Examining the Concavity Property in Detail

Similar to the proof of the convexity of the profit function, we can graph cost as a function of the price of a single input while holding all other prices constant.

If the price of this factor rises, it implies that costs will not decrease (as stated in property 1), but they will increase at a decreasing rate. This occurs because, as the factor becomes more expensive, firms will substitute it with cheaper inputs.

Graphical Exposition

Let z∗z^*z∗ be a cost-minimizing bundle at prices w∗w^*w∗.

Suppose the price of factor 1, w1w_1w1​, changes from w1w_1w1​ to w1w_1w1​. If we continue to behave as we did before, it results in a passive cost line. However, in the real world, firms respond to price changes, which should lead to reduced costs (as it is the minimal cost of production).

Hence, the cost function c(w,y)c(w, y)c(w,y) must be concave with respect to w1w_1w1​.

Shephard’s Lemma

Let xi(w,y)x_i(w, y)xi​(w,y) be the firm’s conditional factor demand for input iii. If the cost function is differentiable at (w,y)(w, y)(w,y) and wi>0w_i > 0wi​>0 for i=1,…,ni = 1, \ldots, ni=1,…,n, then:

xi(w,y)=∂c(w,y)∂wi,i=1,…,n. x_i(w, y) = \frac{\partial c(w, y)}{\partial w_i}, \quad i = 1, \ldots, n. xi​(w,y)=∂wi​∂c(w,y)​,i=1,…,n.
